posted_time: Post  by cavadan » Sat Sep 01, 2007 10:48 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Cavadan,  Pregnancy can increase the risk of blood clots some but for most people this is not an issue.  In your case, since you developed a clot I would suggest you see a hematologist to be evaluated for a condition that would make you at more risk of clotting.  Some possible conditions that would do this are Factor V Liedin, Prothrombin 20210 mutation, Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, and Lupus anticoagulant.  Your chest pains may be due to a condition called pleurisy, which is inflammation of the lining of the lungs/chest wall.  Typically this pain is worsened by deep breaths.  You may also want to ask your doctor about the possibility of systemic lupus erythematosus.  SLE can be associated with hypercoagulation (via the antiphospholipids) and pleurisy as well as other possible causes of the chest pain.  It is most commonly diagnosed in women in their young childbearing age (late teens to early twenties).  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Oct 06, 2007 1:15 pm

author: warwiac  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Sep 09, 2007 3:41 am
title: Chest Pain
content: Hello:    I am a 45 yr old male with a history of high blood pressure & high cholesterol and a family history of heart disease. Recently whenever I am extremely irritated or angry, I have felt an intense almost cramp like pain in my chest.  This stops me in my tracks and when I calm down the pain subsides. However I have a residual soreness/tingling in my chest and left arm for several hours afterwords. I have had 2 such episodes in the past 6 months. I am currently on norvac and zocor. I have had two stress tests in the past 3 years (the treadmill ones) and pass each one with flying colors. I have never had these episodes triggered by exercise only by being very angry or upset.  I visited my doctor after the first episode, and he did not think it was heart related but rather digestive related /heartburn sort of thing.  I believe he feels I'm a hypochondriac. However the pain I experience is real and not like anything I've ever experienced before.  My question is what does this sound like? How concerned should I be? And what is my next step in determining what is going on?  thanks.
posted_time: Post  by warwiac » Sun Sep 09, 2007 3:59 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Your doctor may be right - you could have esophogeal reflux because the symptoms you describe could fit this scenario.  Stomach acid is VERY strong and if it splashes up into your esophagus, the result can be very painful as well as damaging to the tissues.  Intense feelings can also alter stomach acid and trigger such a response.    Of course it could also fit other disorders, such as panic attacks.  Given the identifiable trigger is anger, either scenario is possible.  Our bodies have their own ways of protecting themselves and when you find yourself in "fight or flight" mode, all kinds of physical symptoms can appear intensely and very suddenly.  When breathing is affected there is also the possibility it could be lung related or involving the chest wall muscle and/or ribs.  Pericarditis (inflammation of the outer sac lining of the heart) is also a possibility.    This is not all-inclusive.  Other disorders could also cause your symptoms.  Stay with your doctor until you get a satisfactory answer or until it gets better on its own.    I would not get overly worried about this unless it gets markedly worse or it feels like a heart attack  - pressure, squeezing or dull ache felt in the center of the chest (not actually over the heart) that is usually brought on with exertion and relieved by rest and possibly radiating to neck, back, arm, abdomen.  I know you have said exercise does not bring this on but it is something to be alert to.   Meanwhile, follow your doctor's advice in observing for possible causes, treating stomach acid, etc.    Best wishes

content: I'm a 32 year old male. I've been smoking for about 9 years. My wife and I recently had our first child and I promised myself I'd quit when she was born. posted_time: Post  by dialed1 » Sat Sep 22, 2007 3:35 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I would not expect this response in quitting but congratulations on your determination to do it for your health as well as for that of your family - including the example you are setting for your child.    If the shortness of breath continues, I would consult a doctor but it may be a bit of a panicky feeling happening related to your decision to quit smoking.  By the way, don't be mislead about filters if they are attached to the cigarettes.  The marketing makes it sound like they are safer, but there are so many poisons involved, this is a mere drop in the bucket.  The kind of filter prescribed by a doctor and which you add with each cigarette can help reduce the nicotine consumed and help with the withdrawal symptoms.  If you would like more information to help you quit, contact the American Lung Association (also on the net).  Your local health department may also offer assistance, counseling and even medications to help.    Good luck with this.

title: [no title]
content: Thank you, Doctor, for replying to my question.  Now I would like to know what other reason could cause tachycardia?  I was having a lot of stomach problems about that time. When I took a gulp of really cold orange juice, it started up.  Could this cause it?
posted_time: Post  by Narda99 » Fri Sep 28, 2007 3:16 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are many causes of tachycardia.  It can occur with low blood pressures to compensate, or with anxiety.  Drinking cold beverages does not typically cause a faster heart rate.  The cold beverage may have caused some stimulation of the vagal nerve that runs near the esophagus.  This could cause some initial slowing of the heart rate with a secondary tachycardia to compensate.  (This is a bit of a stretch but possible.)  Seeing your cardiologist will be helpful for you.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Fishfarmer,  Your symptoms do sound like they may be coming from a heart issue. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - It is difficult to get a fix on the effectiveness of your meds as you use such small doses. However, you are correct in your observation that your vital signs all fall within the normal range, especially for one with chronic anxiety/agoraphobia, which is most certainly your most important problem at present.   While you said you are taking 1/2 a 25 mg atenolol tablet, which is a low dose, you are taking that 3 times per day if I read your post right. That would mean you are taking a total of 37.5 mg per day. Since atenolol is a drug normally taken once in 24 hours, you are actually getting a decent dose, so your perception that all drugs are less effective for you may not be true in all cases, as the atenolol is still not overriding the amount of adrenaline you are generating because of your anxiety level. Then again, you take a miniscule dose of clonazepam (a drug which works great along with a beta blocker for your kind of chronic anxiety). Your body could be reacting to the low dose by not doing much of anything new. This could be the answer to your question. I would add, however, for what it's worth, that nothing new or worrisome seems to have evolved either. Your chronic level of anxiety is rather high, and that's where the real attention needs to be focused. The chest pains you describe are classic for generalized anxiety and not at all like cardiac pains, so hopefully that wiill be of some reassurance to you.  By all means try and work your way outside and to the doctor's office. I know how difficult this can be, but it is essential that you not self-medicate and that you be certain you're taking the drugs as prescribed. Besides, every trip out to somewhere is a step toward your ultimate freedom from agoraphobia. You're too young to be trapped that way.   Best of luck to you and please do stay in touch.

posted_time: Post  by muin » Sat Aug 25, 2007 11:25 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Muin,  Your pulmonary pressures are slightly elevated.  This is a known occurrence with COPD.  Seeing your doctor about this is important to see if any specific treatment is needed for it.  Sometimes the pressure is slightly elevated but not enough to need treatment.  In these cases it is followed closely.  Other times treatment is indicated.  The pericardial effusion, if minimal, will likely resolve on its own.  It can be caused by many different causes, including viral infections.  It is likely that this will be followed without treatment to make sure it is getting better.  The cardiologist will be able to tell you much more about your condition.  Follow up is important.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Joyina,  Your pain may be due to a pulled muscle.  Rib area muscles can take a while to heal because almost any move we make (including breathing) uses these muscles. title: Flutter in my chest like a rush of adrenaline to the heart
content: Hi,  Please could anyone help me? Im a 23 year old male, and i have always been very fit and healthy. I  have never had any previous health issues.  About 6 months ago i noticed a flutter in my chest which is difficult to describe - like a localised rush of adrenaline where my heart is, which lasts for just a second or so and happens maybe 2-3 times a day. Soon after, In addition to the flutters i became very aware of my heart and can often feel it thumping (like its beating harder than normal). Recently i have had a mild ache in my left arm/shoulder too! I don't feel dizzy, breathless or have significant chest pain when symptoms occur and my ECG, Echo, X-Ray and Blood test are apparently all normal. It doesnt seem to be effected by alcohol, caffeine or exercise either. However, im certain that there's something wrong, and its not just anxiety, and its worrying me so much that its taking over my life.   Can anyone offer any advice? It would be very much appreciated
posted_time: Post  by mnqcljsm » Mon Sep 03, 2007 7:45 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mnqcljsm,  What you are experiencing may be a heart rhythm called supraventricular tachycardia.  The ECG may be normal if not done during one of these episodes.  You may need to have a holter monitor test done.  This is basically a 24 hour ECG that can hopefully document the heart rhythm during one of the episodes.  This is the best way to find out what the heart is doing when you feel the fluttering.  Usually a cardiologist orders one of these although your primary care doctor may also be able to do this.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by chucky83 » Sun Aug 12, 2007 8:55 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Chucky83,  There are a few possibilities.  Anxiety can definitely cause symptoms like you are describing.  Essentially this is a panic attack.  It can occur without warning and often is accompanied by feelings of dread or fear.  The anxiety causes adrenaline to be released.  The adrenaline then causes the heart to race, the palms to get sweaty and the other symptoms to occur.  Another possibility is that you are having episodes of too low blood pressure.  In response, the heart speeds up.  The low blood pressure can make a person feel dizzy or get light headed.  It can also induce seizures.  Hyperthyroidism can cause some of these symptoms also.  This can be tested for with a simple blood test.  Having a thorough physical exam can help guide the work up for this so seeing your doctor is important.  Best wishes.

author: kconner  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sat Aug 11, 2007 1:34 pm
title: HOCM in the family - who should be tested?
content: My father was diagnosed with hypertrophic Obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM).  Because of 'genetic nature' or high hereditary likelihood, His cardiologist was insistent that every child and grandchild be tested by echo.    To date every child has been tested and all but one of the grandchildren.  For some reason, my daughter's pediatrician did not feel it was reasonable to perform the test.    While everyone is still negative - my sister (43) did show up with some enlargement and evidence of a previous heart event (ekg).  my brother also had some anomalies.    My daughter (18) is overweight, with cholesterol and blood pressure issues intermittently.    Should I pursue the echo with another physician or simply let it go?    Thank you!!
posted_time: Post  by kconner » Sun Aug 12, 2007 12:39 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kconner,  HOCM is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.  Other cases are from spontaneous mutations of the involved genes.  With autosomal dominant inheritance there is essentially a 50% chance that any children could have the disease.  It is for this reason that it is recommend that all direct relatives be screened.  If it has not appeared in the parents it is less likely to appear in the grandchildren as it would be presumed that the parents did not get the affected gene and they are spared the disease.  An exception would be that the parent may not have developed symptoms yet and may still be able to pass on the gene.  So, there are a few ways to look at it.  If the child's parents do not have the disease the chances of it being passed on it is small so the grandchild may not need to be screened.  On the other hand it is perfectly reasonable to have the child screened also since it is relatively simple.    Really, it comes down to your comfort level with the risk.  The risk is low but some people need to know.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Aug 18, 2007 12:57 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi FloridaCountryBoy,  There are a few possibilities.  With you saying that breathing makes it worse, pleurisy is a possibility.  This is a condition where the lining of the lungs/chest wall becomes inflamed.  It can be quite painful.  Another possibility is costochondritis.  This is a condition where the cartilage portion of the rib becomes inflamed.  This pain is usually made worse by pressing on the area.  Both are treated with anti-inflammatories.  If your pain persists I would recommend you follow up with your doctor.  Best wishes.

title: Constant Chest Pain
content: Age:52 Male, 6'1", 335 lbs., 185 total cholestorol, HDL, LDL in line, HBP -controlled. non-smoker, no family history, sedentary lifestyle. Medications:toprol XL 100mg, linisipril 20mg, cardura 2mg, Plavix, Prevacid.  Went in to see my regular doctor with chest pain and slight dizziness. Ran EKG, was abnormal compared to one taken one year prior during routine physical. Sent to hospital, had EKG, same results, also chest X-Ray, ecocardigram, complete blood work. Results: Not having heart attack at that time, but some damage and scarring from previous MI. I also have GERD.   Question: I have almost constant left side chest pain which occasionally is also present in left arm. It doesn't seem to be affected by diet, exercise, and is not helped by antacids either. No history of panic attacks or similar, but frustrated. Not convinced it is heart related (though I have some heart problems), but if acid reflux related, shouldn't it be helped by the prevacid and antacids? It never completely goes away, and severity varies.
posted_time: Post  by Goodwolf21 » Mon Jul 23, 2007 3:30 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: HI Goodwolf21,  Chest pain can be caused by several things.  When the heart is involved it is always best to be sure that the pain isn't related to the heart.  If you have a cardiologist it is probably time to stop in again and make sure all is good.  Reflux can sometimes be severe and not be initially responsive to medications.  You may also want to be tested for H. Pylori, a bacteria that can cause ulcers and gastritis.  Follow up with your doctor is important.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Porschedrifter,  I'm not sure I can fully explain your symptoms.  It is a little hard to interpret your heart sounds without actually listening to you to correlate the sounds with your pulse but I suspect you may be having intermittent PVC's (premature ventricular contractions).  These can make the heart rate seem quite irregular.  Typically a few of them is considered normal.  Too many can be a problem.  You may want to have your actual thyroid hormone levels checked as some of your symptoms fit with a thyroid imbalance.    I would recommend you follow up with your doctor to discuss your symptoms further.  They are a little suspicious and warrant a full physical examination/evaluation.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thyroid levels can easily be checked by a simple blood test.  The test is for TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone) and generally also T4 (an actual thyroid hormone).  Most labs are able to do this test and results come back quickly.  Best wishes.

author: willyoueraseit  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Jul 22, 2007 10:33 pm
title: chest pain?
content: For about a week or so now, I have been having very random chest pains on my left side only right over my heart. They tend to be very very sharp to the point they stop me in my tracks and I have to sit down. They are very sharp and feel like someone is sitting on my chest. I am not having any shortness of breath, just very sharp pains in the left side of my chest. Ive just recently started taking birthcontrol (ortho tri-cyclen lo) for medical reasons because I recently found out I have PCOS (poly cystic ovarian syndrome) and I am wondering if my birth control could be the cause of my chest pains because I do smoke and I do smoke more than 15 per day. Any help/advice?
posted_time: Post  by willyoueraseit » Sun Jul 22, 2007 10:37 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hello Willyoueraseit,  I'm sure one of the big questions that you've thought is "is this related to my heart?"  This is what most people with chest pain worry about.  Heart chest pain is usually not described as sharp and is generally more of a dull diffuse pressure that is a little difficult to pinpoint to one specific area.  Your pain that you are describing sounds to me more like pleurisy or costochondritis.  Pleurisy is inflammation of the lung lining.  It can cause very severe shortness of breath and chest pain.  Often it is made worse by deep breathing.  Costochondritis is inflammation of the cartilage of the rib.  This pain is often reproduced by pressing on the area where the pain is. Both these generally will resolve over time and often can be helped with anti-inflammatory medication.    I would recommend you see your doctor if this pain continues.  Also, just in case you weren't aware, smoking and birth control pills is often a bad combination.  The reason is that both smoking and birth control pills increase the risk of developing deep vein clots with subsequent risk of them breaking off and traveling to the lungs (called a pulmonary embolism).  These can be quite dangerous.  I'm sure you've been told but I would be remiss if I did not advise you to stop smoking.    Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Jul 23, 2007 1:41 am

The pains come randomly when I'm doing basically anything from walking to doing nothing and just laying in my bed.. which is why I thought it may be due to my birth control because I am on my first pack of birth control at the moment and it started 2 weeks after I started taking them. I smoke anywhere from 1-2 packs of cigarettes a day and I am only 18 but I am sure at any age it is not a good mix. I told my doctor I did not want the birth control because of my smoking and I do not really like taking pills. I basically went ahead and took it because I was told it was help my pain for my PCOS but not until the 2nd pack even though Im taking Prescription strength Naproxen for pain during my menstrual period... and I also gave in to the birth control because I was told it may increase my chances of getting pregnant one day as I do not ovulate due to my PCOS. Should I consider going to check in my doctor about my birth control and see if maybe switching would be a good idea or just going off of it entirely?

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hmm... the chest pain may be related to the birth control pills since it started at the same time although it probably isn't due to pulmonary emboli.    I would recommend that you discuss this with your doctor.  You may be able to try a different pill that may not cause your chest pain.  There are literally hundreds of birth control pills.  Many have different hormones that  may not cause your symptoms.  The clotting risk with smoking is low given that you are young but it does increase your risk by taking contraceptives and smoking.  This would also be something to discuss with your doctor.  It may be that your doctor feels the benefits of the contraceptives outweigh the risks.  (Of course, the other solution is to stop smoking :) I promise  I won't say anymore about that.)  Best wishes.

author: whole9yards  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jul 22, 2007 11:47 pm
title: Twisting leads to chest pain
content: Hi. I'm a 36-year-old male. For at least four months now, I have had the same symptom - whenever I twist my torso, I get an intense pain in my sternum (sometimes radiating down into my armpits or pecs). For example - if I'm in the car and want to look behind me, I can't without extreme chest pain. It's very specific to that sternum area. I get the same pain if I try top prop myself up in bed by resting on my elbow on one side or the other. Same pain if I bend from side to side. I thought I noticed a lump under the sternum area today, but I may have always had this. I'm generally really healthy and don't pay too much attention to my body. My doctor thought it might be GERD and put me on Protonix and then Aciphex. Also gave me Mobic. When none of those worked, I went on Celebrex. No relief from the chest pain on any of them. Other than this horrible specific problem, I'm in good shape. Not overweight, no cigarettes or alcohol or even coffee.
posted_time: Post  by whole9yards » Sun Jul 22, 2007 11:59 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Whole9yards,  It sounds as if you may have a condition called costochondritis.  This is where the cartilage portion of the rib (where it connects to the sternum) becomes inflamed.  It can produce quite severe pain.  It is exhacerbated by moving the joint as it would with turning.  I would have expected that this would be a little better with the Mobic or celebrex since they help treat inflammation.  Another possibility is that you have a stress fracture of your sternum.  This would be fairly rare.  It may not be healing well since the area is moved frequently.  I would suggest that you see a sports medicine doctor.  They are the muscle/joint experts and will probably be able to help you figure out what is going on.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I am glad to see you are pursuing this with a doctor.  Probably the most worrisome possibility to me would be unstable angina, which occurs "at rest" and can be quite serious.  Your heart is not getting enough blood and oxygen so it may require an emergency dept. visit.    There are lots of other causes for chest pain such as digestive problem (reflux), inflammation, gallbladder, asthma, pneumonia, pleurisy, muscle strain, anxiety, etc.   So, this may require extensive diagnosis by process of elimination of other causes.  Continue to follow up with your doctor and go in sooner if you have an attack.

author: mathmajor  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Jul 09, 2007 8:44 pm
title: 18-yo with bad symptoms, long read
content: Hello, I'm an 18-year-old male (never smoked, never drinks or does drugs, occasionally does cardio exercises, typically calm and passive) that is very concerned about his health at the moment.  Other diagnoses: fatty liver, high liver enzymes, obese (275 lbs on 6'1" frame, about 36-ish BMI). Previously diagnosed as mildly asthmatic in gradeschool, lots of bronchitis when I was a baby. No surgeries. Mother has had a heart attack at 48 and renal failure, rampant family history of diabetes but I have been checked numerous times and I don't have it. Meds: have been on Meridia appetite control meds and zyrtec but haven't taken them for a week or so.  For probably 6-9 months now I had been experiencing what I would describe as mild bothersome pressures or slight pain in the left chest area, usually in different places but always on the left side of my vertical divide. I went to my doctor. BP was normal. Did full blood work and everything. My cholesterol and thyroid are normal. Nothing out of the ordinary except liver enzymes which sparked more blood tests and I'm negative for hepatitis, hemochromatosis (some family has it), etc.  Had both a liver and heart ultrasound. That's how I discovered the fatty liver and my heart test came back normal. I've had several EKGs, all normal. I have a small hole in my heart from birth but have been told it's not an issue.  I've been on a high-fiber, no caff, low junk food and lower fat diet for two months now. I lost 25 lbs. so far (started around 300) and have started exercising more. That's where the story begins.  On Friday July 6 I pushed myself too hard on my exercise bike. When I got off my pulse would not return to normal. I got chills, dizziness, weakness, nausea, and moderate dull pain/heaviness over my left chest area. I do not have a history of panic attacks but I was in a bit of a panic at the time naturally. Went to the ER.  My BP was high, I was a bit dehydrated, oxygen level hovered between 97-100%, and my pulse never left the 115-140 range until I slept. EKG was normal, just a bit fast. Chest xray normal. Was admitted overnight and the "heart attack enzymes" they were talking about never showed up in any test. The cardiologist released me even though I had constant (90% of the time) upper-left chest heaviness and often had some trouble breathing. My sit-stand BP was fairly constant. (A little high like 150/80 though.) They scheduled a stress test Thurs Jul 13.  That night I had more severe bouts of chest heaviness. It got hard to breathe and I couldn't stand or hardly talk for a while. We called the cardiologist I saw in the hospital and he still thinks none of this is heart related. He said it might be digestional or musculoskeletal. He prescribed me a xanax generic and told me to take advil and pepcid. This combination helped some (I burped a lot which seemed to stop the severe bouts of heaviness).  The next day I woke up with some heaviness again. Went upstairs, took a shower, made breakfast. Took my pepcid, a low dose bayer, my xanax (the heaviness got me a bit worried). Sat down on the couch to eat my multigrain flakes and soy milk. Started getting dizzy, nauseous, and hard to breathe. I felt a strange tingle in my left arm. I tried to stand and nearly fainted but I could still walk. I got chills. We went to the ER and were seen after 2 hours. My pulse was normal 70-100 ish, but BP a little high 140/80 or so. Got a chest scan with iodine, came back normal. I was out within 3 hrs.  My cardiologist and doctor both predict my stress test will be negative and that I have no cardio trouble. My regular doctor even said that the stress test is a waste of $. He thinks it's digestion.  I still have constant (nearly 100% of the time) pressure with frequent mild left-chest pain, usually dull squeeze pain. Sometimes I feel it in my left arm or left armpit (rarely, maybe once in the back) and I'm constantly slightly light headed. This has been going on since my overexertion 80 hrs ago and not a minute before.  I am so confused. My family is worried sick, and so am I. Sometimes it feels like I'm about to have a heart attack at any time and I'm only 18. I go back to school in a one-horse town in August and am afraid for my life if I'm by myself and this keeps up.  Thanks mathmajor

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I am glad that you have had these workups with physicians and so far everything comes out "normal."  This at least lets us know it's not an obvious serious concern, requiring immediate attention.  Of course that doesn't relieve your anxiety bout it very much.    I would suggest you get an appointment with a mental health professional. Perhaps you could benefit from some relaxation therapy, meditation or other therapy that would allow your mind to work on the problem.  As you mentioned your high anxiety, I assume this may actually be a factor so learning to manage such an attack is important. You may be able to stop it at an early sign, thus avoiding the more serious attack.    Learning these skills could be very helpful in other aspects of your life as well.  I am not saying it is emotionally based, but control could begin on this level anyway.  Continuing with a regular physician (family practice, internal medicine, etc.) to find the cause is also important, so continue with this follow up care..    Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Chest pain from the heart is generally a vague feeling of severe pressure.  It seldom is described as sharp or stabbing.  Also, usually one is not able to pinpoint the exact area of pain.  If these fit your pain you should see your doctor and possibly a cardiologist.  If your pain is more sharp or better localized it is more likely to be something other than the heart.  Common causes of chest pain include reflux, pleurisy and costochondritis.  Pleurisy is an inflammation of the lining of the lungs/chest wall.  Costochondritis is inflammation of the cartilage portion of the rib.  Pleurisy is often made worse by deep breaths.  Costochondritis pain can generally be reproduced by pressing on the area where it hurts.  If the pain persists you should follow up with your doctor.  Reflux, pleurisy and costochondritis all have treatments and can generally be made better.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear yicker, I appreciate that you have taken your symptoms seriously enough to have a thorough evaluation by a cardiologist.  If all the tests came back negative for any cardiac problems, then it may be of value to explore non heart related scenarios.  It is very difficult to address issues that can contribute to either panic ( as your one doctor suggested) or to other somatic displays of stress or fear over the internet.  Everyone's tolerance to stress is different, and can even vary for that individual from moment to moment or day to day.  At whatever time the chest pains first began, or whatever precipitating factors may have triggered them, the ongoing experience of unresolved chest pain certainly becomes to some degree self-perpetuating.  Whenever a clenched jaw and a realization that one's coping mechanism is less than successful, then it may be a good idea to explore your concerns with a mental health professional.  This does not mean you are crazy, nor does it mean you are mentally "ill".  It only means that, as everyone does at some time or another, you may need some additional help in sorting out your current stressors, and in so doing may be able to find a way to identify the chest pain, and put it to rest. You have been so detailed in describing your current concerns, it is clear you have taken the time to really try to recognize  your reactions to situations (such as to people screaming around you).  That is the first step to finding the best way to address the issues.  Your town may have resources that are free or on a sliding scale to help you. Please consider exploring them.

author: Mojee  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Mon Jul 09, 2007 9:04 am
title: Chest Pressure
content: Hi, I'm a 27 year old female, overweight.  My mother died at 45 from "hardening of the arteries", same with her father.  I started having chest pressure and pain around 2001, had many heart tests, came back normal, was diagnosed then with panic/anxiety disorder and was put on anti-depressants.  So, I've stopped taking my anti-depressants for about 7 months.  I've developed chest pressure and achey pain in the center of my chest that seems to radiate outwards in the chest.  In march 2007 I went and had a echo and a stress test, both came back normal.  These chest sensations have gotten the better of me now, and today I'm going for an electrolite stress test? I'm really worried, because everything on the internet tells me that my symptoms are heart related.  I have had a chest xray last week, and blood tests last week, all came back normal.  Could they have missed something in March, and really I have angina or some heart disease?  I do understand that I have anxiety and would benefit from going back on medication...but I'm so concerned about my heart right now!
posted_time: Post  by Mojee » Mon Jul 09, 2007 9:12 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Mojee, One of the greatest drives of all humankind is to be "normal".  Well, I defy anyone to come up with a pure definition of normal!  What is normal for one is completely abnormal to someone else.  I am not sure why you elected to quit taking your panic and anxiety medications, but as you have noticed, at the very least there is still a component of this anxiety reigning in your life right now. I realize you want to be sure that your heart is healthy, yet since it is a recognized fact that panic and anxiety can cause the symptoms of chest pain, it certainly would help for you to consider going back on your medications. If nothing else, then whatever gets discovered regarding your heart will be much more tolerable than it is right now!  And if in the process, you find complete relief from the chest pain, then you have won twice over.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear konijiba, Chest pain, even in a young and apparently very active man, can be caused by several different sources.  The chest houses not only the heart, but as you are aware, also part of your gastric system: specifically esophagus and upper part of the stomach.  Reflux can indeed cause chest pain.  So  can lung problems, and of course your heart.  What relieves your pain? Have you taken any over the counter antacids?  (You mention you used to be on Prevacid - did your MD discontinue this medication, or did you?)  Is exercise the only thing that aggravates the pain?  If you are unable to get relief from over the counter medications, and the pain persists, gets worse, or changes character please present to the local emergency room or urgent care center for professional Medical evaluation .

title: Heart attack?
content: Age - 18 Sex - Female Past diagnoses - no known health problems; normal healthy pegnancy 8 months ago (with slight high blood pressure). Past surgeries - none Family history - parents-no health issues, grandfather & grandmother - cancer, great grandmother - heart attack. Current medications - none  A week ago, I developed mild neck pain, which felt like overuse from sitting incorrectly in front of the computer too long. Neck pain stayed for about a week. Mild upper back pain that started a day after the neck pain, but only lasted a few days. I have been skipping lunch (unintentionally...I keep forgetting until nearly dinnertime) for the past few weeks. (I don't know if the aforementioned symptoms are related to the rest.) Yesterday I had an episode of shortness of breath that lasted for a few seconds, with no chest pain or other symptoms. However, right after that, I had what I can only describe as a panic attack in which I was hyperventilating, had tingling sensations in both hands/arms and around my mouth and nose, and extreme anxiety. Today I had mild pain in the stomach area, and a sensation like right before vomiting, stomach tightening slightly, and it radiated into the left side of my chest. After that I felt nauseous for about a minute, then it passed and I felt just slightly dizzy and was better in a few minutes. A few hours later, I had a strange feeling in my chest, like the need to burp, but I couldn't burp. This lasted about a minute or so, went away, then came back after a few minutes, then I ate, and I felt better afterwords. Does any of this sound like a cardiac condition? I researched heart attack symptoms on the internet but they all describe a different type of chest sensation than what I was having. I (until about a week ago) ate fast food almost exclusively and don't exercise much besides chasing after a baby, which is why I'm worried about cardiac problems. I have had slightly prehypertensive blood pressure in the past, but for the past few months my BP has been normal. I have no idea about my cholesterol level because I have never had it checked.

title: [no title]
content: Feelings of the heart pounding are relatively common, though generally not all the time.  When a person is quiet and resting the pulse can often be felt.  If you are feeling it all the time it may be related to elevated blood pressure.  Given all the testing you've had, it should be fine to wait until your doctor returns.    If you'd like, you can often stop by a local pharmacy or health center where they often have automatic blood pressure machines.  Keep in mind that these machines may not be 100% accurate and any high blood pressure should be confirmed by your doctor.  Best wishes.

content: 191 is a bit faster than I would expect for an increased heart rate due to exercise.  I would recommend she see her doctor. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - Your slow heart rate is likely the result of your body wanting to gear down and rest. The parasympathetic nervous system (mainly the vagus nerve) tries to but a brake on things when we are fatigued, need sleep, or have just eaten. PVCs will become more frequent when the vagus nerve gets the upper hand from the sympathetic nervous system, whose job is to speed up the heart (among other things). When I read your first post I was wondering if perhaps your blood pressure was a little high. The addendum you tacked on answered that question, and that is probably why you are so aware of the forceful heartbeat. The slower the heart beats, the more time it has to fill. When the pressure is high like that and the rate is slow, a lot of people are much more aware of it than they would be otherwise. It all sounds pretty normal, although it is important to manage the high blood pressure.   Aldomet shouldn't slow your heart rate any further as it is not a beta blocking drug. At any rate, if your EKG is normal (with the exception of the slow rate) then so long as you can function well physically (stand up, walk around, etc., without getting lightheaded) then there's really no problem. However, once you've started the Aldomet, if it is effective, you may have some lightheadedness  upon standing, if only for a little while, so you should be prepared for that and get up slowly at first, so your body can adjust to the drop in blood pressure (which is what we want to take place!). You also may feel tired or drowsy for a period of days after first starting the Aldomet, so don't let that concern you too much.  It sounds as though everything is pretty much in order here. Your ordeal of not having slept for 30 hours would make your body want everything to slow down in order for you to rest and sleep. That would include your heart rate. The pain meds given in the hospital should have cleared your system by now, and while they can sometimes slow the heart rate a little (simply by allowing you to relax) they are not likely the culprit here. I think it is most likely just exhaustion. I hope you get some good sleep and that your BP normalizes quickly.   Please keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Wed Jun 20, 2007 1:00 pm

author: Archiebald  Guest Posts: 29 Joined: Sun Aug 28, 2005 11:20 am
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for the response, how long would it take to recover from this, the heart rate being low is what scares me most.  thanks

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi - I would think that once you are thoroughly rested the rate should start to normalize again. It's hard to say exactly when that might be. The Aldomet may indirectly help keep it a little slower simply because it has a mild, transient sedative effect at first. Also, as a new parent you may not get thoroughly rested for a long time! The important thing is that you are able to function with the slow heart rate and even more important is to control that elevated blood pressure. It wouldn't hurt to get a follow up EKG done at your doctor's after a while, if the slow rate persists, although it is very unlikely to cause problems. If you should experience unusual lightheadedness on standing you should mention this to your doctor. Otherwise I think it's just going to take a little while for things to "reset" themselves, but that is fairly normal, given all the circumstances.   Hope this helps.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - There are a few seemingly minor details left out of your otherwise very thorough report which might be helpful at least in ruling out certain conditions which might be  causing your symptoms.  One, in particular, would be helpful to know: does any sort of bodily movement or posturing elicit or aggravate the pain in your shoulder?   The fact that there are no other symptoms directly associated with the shoulder pain, plus the fact that it is intermittent and has been going on for months now suggest it is unlikely to be cardiac-related. However, there are other possible intra-thoracic causes, most benign, but it  would be nice to at least be rid of the discomfort.   The dilated pupil episode also makes me wonder if there hasn't been some sort of injury to or irritation of the sympathetic nervous system or one of its branches, which could somehow be tied in with the shoulder blade pain. This is  all speculation, of course, and  the  big question still  remains: does any sort of movement cause or worsen the pain? If you could supply that answer it would be a huge help.  Meanwhile  you would  appear to be in general good health and doing the  right things. One of your big tasks will be managing the anxiety, at least until you are able to find an explanation for your other symptoms.  Cardiac risk screening consists of a blood lipids panel (HDL, LDL and VLDL components, with a ratio of HDL to total cholesterol), along with high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) and homocysteine level. It's a very handy way to determine the individual's risk for the development of heart disease, excluding an unusual family history (which always must be factored in).   I'm sorry I can't be of more help at this point,but once the issue of pain upon body movement  is resolved we may be able to narrow the field a little.   I look forward to hearing more from you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello again - You are very welcome. The dilated pupil may well be tied to the lungs in some way, as there is a cranial nerve which travels down into the chest and can be affected by things that have taken place down there, which then show up involving one eye. Usually this is either a drooping eyelid or constricted pupil, not a dilated one, but it still seems plausible, and if that is the case it is likely a very benign thing. (There are at least 47 conditions which can account for pupil dilation, but most of them can be easily ruled out here).  The shoulder blade pain could also be related to something going on inside your thoracic cavity, and since it is not aggravated by movement then it is more likely something internal, although it could be referred from  somewhere other than its apparent location, and it is very difficult to do more than speculate at a distance. A chest x-ray (PA and lateral views) might be useful. An inflammatory process could certainly be at the bottom of this, but it's really hard to tell. The anxiety (which is now probably more situational than anything else) only serves to cloud the picture by adding symptoms. That's one of those unavoidable things that make a good internist invaluable in situations like this.  Wish I could give you something more concrete, but due to the liimitations of this medium that's about the best I can do. Good luck to you with this and do let us know if anything changes.

content: Hello - The good news is you seem to be in  good shape cardiac-wise.  Still, who needs this kind of discomfort? It is likely referred from the upper part of the pleural membrane or diaphragm, quite possibly due to some passing viral infection. It also could  be due to an inflammation of a nerve or blood vessel which travels the  same path as the pain,  which could explain why your now beginning to have headaches with it as well. In most of the above-mentioned  scenarios an NSAID (such as Advil or Aleve) should help a great deal.   If  this continues I'd definitely bring it to the attention of my primary physician.  It's  probably not serious, but there is always that remote potential,  and mainly it is painful and that's just not something you need!  Good luck to you. Hope this  has been of some help.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - If  it weren't for the symptoms coming  before the BP reading this wouldn't have been a concern. It is the symptomology that  makes the reading a slight concern. It is a pretty low reading, although some people do OK  with similar numbers. They are usually petite, however.   If there is any possibility that you've become  dehaydrated then your total fluids and thus blood volume could be depleted. Of course there are other ways blood volume can  become lowered, but they are usually accompanied by some pain or actual trauma. The low BP could also result from some sort of autonomic nervous system incompetence, but you would likely have had this happen before. Then again, everything does have to have a beginning point. If you wind up having to be worked up for this and some neurological basis for a hemodynamic problem is suspected, you could wind up having a tilt-table test. That's not terrible, but hopefully since  this came on abruptly it is caused by a transient, easily correctable problem such as dehydration or fluid volume depletion.   If the  problem still persists as of this exchange, I would definitely bring it to the attention of a physician, simply because it is not normal for you, and it is causing unacceptable symptoms.   Good  luck to you and please do keep us updated.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - What you describe could possibly be some  sort of palpitation (caused by a rapid or irregular heartbeat) but your description makes it sound a little more like fasiculation instead, wherein a small area of voluntary muscle twitches rapidly off and on. If it occurs in close proximity to the area where the costochondritis was located then that's a  possibility. Then again, dexamethasone is a very potent steroid which, in the short term, can cause either palpitations or fasiculations. The drug should have long  since cleared your system by now, but sometimes  those  things are started by something like  that and  then continue on for a while.  One question: does the fluttering sensation last for long durations or merely moments at time? Whatever it  is, if it is sustained for a long time and/or causes other  symptoms  (such as lightheadedness or strong feelings of anxiety) then it would be worth another EKG or perhaps even a Holter monitor or other type of event monitor to determine if it  is  some  sort of heartbeat irregularity. These are usually harmless in young, otherwise healthy people, but if they cause symptoms or otherwise compromise your ability to function then they are worth at least a look.   I strongly suspect, simply by the way you've worded your post, that it is fasicular twitching you're feeling, but it is only speculation. I hope this will at least serve  to ease any concerns you may have. If this problem  continues to trouble you, I  wouldn't hesitate to at least bring it to the attention of your primary physician.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Magenta - While your described symptoms  do not sound cardiac-related, it's of course impossible to know for certain  at a distance, and besides, whatever it is, it has to at least be very annoying. It definitely deserves a doctor's attention.    Having IBS you could be  experiencing referred pain from  the splenic flexure of  your colon (upper left quadrant  of your abdomen), which happens a lot and can show up almost anywhere between the  left abdomen and the left shoulder, with the submammary (beneath the breast) pain being a common place for it to show up. It's good to keep in mind, too, that heart pain is almost always not sharp, stabbing or sudden in nature. The one possible exception to this rule would be  the pain that sometimes  accompanies mitral valve prolapse (MVP), an almost always benign condition that can be accompanied by a lot of odd symptoms and is almost never a cause for concern it itself.   One other non-cardiac possible cause might be costochondritis,  and inflammation of the  carilige in the space between any two or more ribs. Since the pain began with a change in position that is a possibility too. Increased pain on exhalation might also suggest costochondritis, or even a muscle spasm in the chest wall.   Palpitations  are awfully common, and even moreso in people who tend to be anxious or over-stressed.  They are also rarely of any concern, except insofar as they can provoke  a good deal of anxiety.   As you can see, even without any serious heart problem, there are plenty of potential causes of this sort of discomfort, and it  really should be  addressed by a doctor. I hope this serves to ease your mind, and  at the same time encourages you  to have the  thing  looked  into, so that it can be treated and made to go away. It can't be very pleasant, even if it doesn't sound serious.  Good  luck to you. Please keep in touch.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: One possibility is that you are having anxiety attacks.  These frequently will give fast heart rates and feelings as if one is going to die.  Also, anxiety tends to be associated with depression.  If the attacks only happen while walking you may need to have a stress cardiac test to see what your rhythm is during the episodes.  A holter monitor or event recorder may also help to capture the heart rhythm during an attack.  Looking at the rhythm while the symptoms are there are the most helpful.  I would recommend talking to your doctor about some of these tests to see if they would be appropriate for you.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by MALICE » Mon Jun 04, 2007 6:14 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Given all your normal testing it is unlikely to be the heart.  Also, heart pain very rarely presents as sharp pain.  It typically is described as more of a dull severe pressure that is difficult to pinpoint to one specific area of the chest.  It may be that you have a bit of costochondritis.  This is inflammation of the rib cartilage.  This pain can be reproduced by pushing on the inflamed area.  You may also have some areas of pleurisy, inflammation of the lining of the lungs/chest wall.  This pain can be quite sharp and severe.  It is often worse with deep breathing.  You may also want to try an antacid liquid during the pain episodes to see if they are potentially related to reflux.  Without some fast heart rate and shortness of breath it seems less likely to be related to anxiety; however, this by no means rules it out.  It does not seem likely to be anything life-threatening at this point given all your normal tests.  If the episodes persist I would recommend that you follow up with your doctor.  Best wishes.

While hospitalized I had a nuclear test on my lungs, and have had many ecocardiagrams which are fine.  My Doctor in the hospital was an internal medicine Doctor and a Pulmonary Doctor.  I was given a test wher I had to breathe into a machine and push a ball up in the air.  The person giving the test accused me of not even trying.  I was blowing as hard as I could. The Doctor also did a cat scan and checked my sinus cavity..I think that is what it is called.  Also, my legs feel extremely heavy when I climb stairs.  Like they have weight tied around them. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello there - OK, let's see. You were having trouble breathing and responded well to what we'll assume was a puff or two of albuterol. You have a family history of asthma and the doctor prescribed a bronchodilating inhaler for you, which seems to be working. I hate to be sarcastic about your doctor, who may have been splitting some semantic hairs, but it would seem you do have asthma, at least according to everything you've written here.   Of course there are other problems which can cause bronchoconstriction, but essentially that's asthma, even if it is secondary to some other problem. It really sounds like that's one part of your collection of things, and the rest certainly fit in well with the diagnosis of FM.   Asthma can sometimes be caused by not only postnasal sinus drainage but also nocturnal esophageal reflux, which often causes the patient to wake up at night with a hacking or tickling cough, shortness of breath, or high-airway wheezing. Again, it is still asthma. It may be splitting hairs, but that's what it sounds like has been happening.   Best of luck to you and please keep us updated.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Wetodd, I strongly suggest you ask your cardiologist to allow you to undergo a complete heart evaluation, to include Echodoppler, Carotid doppler, Bilateral subclavian ultrasounds, possibly even Cerebral angiogram.  Have they been able to check your blood pressure on BOTH arms during one of your episodes?  There is a syndrome called Subclavian Steal Syndrome in which stenosis in the proximal subclavian artery can cause abnormal blood flow to the brain and sometimes to the heart.  The quickest check for this is to do blood pressures in both arms.  The natural laws of physics includes facts like fluids flow toward the path of least resistance, and if the pressure of the blood toward the brain is unequal L to R, the blood actually drains away from the brain instead of feeding to it.  This can cause dizziness, and you could possibly feel the pulse stronger on the non obstructive side.  Many things can contribute to cardiac arrhythmias, and it sounds like you need a full hospital stay with complete workup to determine if there is any abnormal pathology or electrical activity regarding your heart.  Supraventricular tachycardia can cause some of the sensations you describe as well, and a Nuclear stress test may be of value in the diagnostic workup.  Has your cardiologist done or offered any of the above tests? Do you have any of the results of the lab work I am sure they did for you?  Is there any particular time of the day these episodes occur?  With a strong family history of severe cardiac problems, you should continue to try to find out what is wrong.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello shaz29 - This sensation is often mentioned by frustrated patients who are unable to assign a cause to it. The fact is sometimes there is no truly solid cause that can be found. Some possibilities (all benign) are: nerve irritation, chest wall inflammation, costrochondritis (inflammation of the cartilege where the ribs connect to the sternum), and even mitral valve prolapse (MVP), an almost always benign and sometimes controversial finding which is associated with a very long list of odd symptoms that would otherwise be impossible to explain. Your complaint is one of them.   If you can reproduce any local soreness or tenderness by pressing on the immediately affected area, it is probably costrochondritis. Otherwise the most likely cause is an irritated nerve.   Best of luck to you and keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Thu May 03, 2007 1:19 pm

author: shaz29  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Mon Apr 23, 2007 3:13 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thanks so much for the advice... i hope you are right... i don't feel as though its costo... would an irritated nerve cause burning pin prick feelings behind the sternum?(sometimes feel it on the sternum itself).. i thought nerves would just be related to the muscle area and not the bone?
posted_time: Post  by shaz29 » Thu May 10, 2007 3:11 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Shazad - We've actually got miles and miles of nerve servicing most every part of our bodies, even the skin and the very thin fatty layer over the sternum. as well as the bone itself (although it's probably not actually coming from the bone). There's also the common and annoying phenomenon of referred pain (or sensation) from some indirect location. It sounds as though you may have an a mild neuritis (inflammation of one or more nerves) somewhere in the general vicinity of your sternum. This generally presents itself as a pinprick sensation, pins-and-needles, numbness, tingling, or burning over the affected area. Sometimes the cause can be viral, sometimes orthopedic.   If the sensation continues and is bothersome (which I would expect it would be) then I would suggest bringing to the attention of an internist or general practitioner, since cardiac causes seem to be pretty much out of the question.   Best of luck to you and please do keep us updated.

content: Hi - Amytriptyline has been used a good deal to block nerve pain such as may be what you are having. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: You're welcome. I misspoke (or my brain did anyway) when I typed "neuroleptic." I actually was thinking of anti-seizure drugs instead, and some of those now being used to block nerve pain are gabapentin (as Neurontin), pregabalin (as Lyrica), and a number of others. They are generally less likely to cause the lethargy, sleepiness, etc., that most tricyclics can cause, and are in general safer and more effective.   Hope this is helpful.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Amytriptilyine is a very utilitarian drug. It has many possible uses, and pain management is a big one. While not everyone responds the same way to every drug (which is why there are so many) it certainly is true that many people get relief from headache with amytriptilyne, as well as relief from the pain of shingles, various kinds of neuritis and neuralgia, etc. It is a very good idea to take it at bedtime, since that way the body has time to adjust to the drowsiness-inducing quality of the drug, something that should wear off with time.   Good luck to you with this. Give it a few days to reach full effectiveness, and do let us know how things work out.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Rochelle - The reaction to ibuprofin (as  Motrin) makes  some sense, since this drug can really irritate the stomach lining. Some  people are more sensitive to it than others, but since you say you "abused" it when you were younger there's a chance that either your stomach lining just doesn't want to see it anymore,  or even that you've developed a  rare allergic reaction to it. It's probably wise to avoid this drug in light of the history.  The apparent reaction to acetominophen is also rather unusual and may have had some other component involved that we  don't know about, but you did exceed the recommended dosage by about 50 per cent. That wouldn't normally cause the kind  of  reaction you describe,  but it's possible. More likely, though, it sounds as though you experienced a panic attack, which would be  unrelated to the Tylenol.   One reason this might  have happened  (or even both reactions) is that  since you probably have a tilted (inverted?) uterus, your periods  are far more uncomfortable  than normal,  and this  could have triggered some sort of reflex response.   I would  strongly suggest you bring this to the attention of a gynecologist, who may well prescribe a different medication for  the  painful periods. You obvioiusly are going to need something at least briefly during those times. There are alternatives prescription pain medications that hopefully wouldn't affect you the way the over-the-counter ones  have. Tramadol comes to mind as a likely effective and  innocuous prescription drug you could use on a limited basis if your doctor feels it is appropriate.  I hope this is of some help.

I've never had that problem until the tylenol which is why I ask.  Rochelle

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Rochelle - I'm glad you'll be getting this checked. There's probably something that will work a lot better for you. I certainly hope so!   Panic attacks can be triggered by a lot of things, but usually there is some underlying condition or situation that leaves the patient prone to this happening. In your case it could be as simple as the hormonal change that takes place routinely during mestruation. Combine that with the excruciating pain and maybe some stressor that normally might go overlooked, and all of a sudden there's all this strange stuff happening with no apparent explanation. It wouldn't necessarily be directly related to the Tylenol, but possibly indirectly (for instance, a reaction to the extra 500 mg. may have made you feel ill, which could make for a bad coincidence, since it was during your period and also at the height of your physical pain). Sometimes it just takes one straw to set off something like that. It's worth considering, anyway, I think.   Good luck to you and please stay in touch.

title: Chest Pain
content: I'm a 36 year old male.  About 2 years ago I went to my doctor with chest tightness and pain.  He did a physical with an ekg and said everything was normal and blamed it on anxiety.  Well, it never really went away and lately it has become worse.  My chest feels tight all the time and I get some sharp pains randomly on the left side of my chest about 2 inches below my collar bone.  About 2 weeks ago I started to get very bad indigestion which I've never had before.  The  chest pain happens when I'm relaxed or when I exercise, it really doesn't matter.  I'm starting to worry a lot and I think that is making it worse or giving me an ulcer!  What should I do?  Go back to my doctor again?  See some sort of specialist?  Not sure what to do...  Oh yeah, I'm not taking any medication or had any history of any illness or diseases.  My Grandfather and Grandmother had heart issues late in life but that's about it.  Thanks,  Mike
posted_time: Post  by MikeB. » Tue May 08, 2007 4:36 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mike - One thing you said is interesting: "My chest feels tight all the time." Is that literally the case, or do you mean  it feels that way frequently? The difference is that most cardiac-related issues which cause chest  tightness would not be constant for two years without something dramatic having happend a long time ago. On the other hand, anxiety can cause a  fairly constant, vague sense of tightness in the chest. So can  asthma,  which more and more often is uncovered recently because of complaints of chest tightness rather than  wheezing or shortness of breath.  Is it possible you might  have asthma? (There is a very simple test to rule this out). The doctor who pronounced the problem  anxiety-related is probably right, but at a distance and with no specific test findings it is difficult to say with any degree of certainty. Did  the doctor at least perform a 12-lead EKG? Anxiety also frequently can cause sharp,  stabbing, left-sided chest pains, especially in  the area of the left breast, though usually not so high up. This pain  you describe also could be  related to a respiratory problem such as asthma, since one may be using accessory muscles,  which makes them  sore and  painful.  It's just a thought.   If your doctor did even a cursory cardiac workup it would help to know that and would help support the anxiety theory. There  is also the possibility of chronic chest wall irritation, which is not dangerous or serious, but can  cause the same  sort of pains and discomforts that you describe. This is usually treated with antiinflammatory meds such as ibuprofin.   I hope this helps put your mind  at east. If you have any more information I'd be happy to hear it.  Good  luck  to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: You're very welcome. Absent any hint of asthma and knowing that your doctor did do what sounds like a 12-lead EKG (the usual), then anxiety is certainly at least a possibility, and it would seem far less likely that the problem is cardiac-related. It may well be a chronic chest wall irritation or inflammation, such as Tietz' Syndrome, which is inflammation of the cartilege between one or more ribs where they join the sternum.  One way to check for this would be to exert moderate pressure on the affected area with one or two fingers. If you find the area is tender when  pressed upon, you almost certainly have Tietz' (or costochondritis). This responds well to OTC drugs like ibuprofin (as Advil or Motrin). If there's no local tenderness then anxiety becomes a more likely cause.  Even if the pain is frequent rather than constant, if it were cardiac-related, it would likely have produced more or worsening symptoms long before now.  Actually I'm just outside of DC, so we're practically neighbors!   Good luck to you. Let me know if you've checked for local tenderness.

author: senagod  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Apr 30, 2007 3:44 pm
title: Anxiety or something else?
content: Hello. I'm a 34 year old female, pack a day smoker. Two months ago I had a burning pain in the right side of my chest, above the breast, towards the armpit with a rapid heart rate and a hot feeling that goes to the back of my neck. Went to the ER, had stress test, chest X-ray, CT scan, echocardiogram, EKG, and bloodwork. All came back negative. Went to the family doctor, who said costochondritis and gave me ibuprofen. Went back to the ER two weeks later with similar symptoms. My pulse was 120. They tested blood for thyroid and came back negative. Went to the cardiologist who saw me in the ER. He said it could be a sign of perimenopause, told me to stop taking The Pill and put me on 25mg of Atenolol.   I will have a string of good days and then I'll have a day where I have pain on either side of my chest, never lasting longer than a couple of seconds, and a rapid heart rate. It's making me tired.  My appetite is gone. I only manage to eat one meal a day and I've lost over 20 pounds, from 148 to 127.  My family doctor sent me for more bloodwork and all they found was slighly high cholesterol. 221 total, 132 bad cholesterol.  I saw a second cardiologist today. The nurse did an EKG and pulse was 105. When the cardiologist checked my pulse, it was 80. He said it's not my heart and that it's either an autoimmune disease or it's anxiety/depression. I don't feel depressed or anxious about anything. Life is going good except for this health problem.  Please help. I don't want to go on anxiety medication, especially if it's unwarranted. Thank you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello senigod - I will reluctantly skip the sermon about smoking. You already know this will cause you problems that may eventually become life-threatening and will worsen any existing problems, no matter what they are. Nope, that wasn't the sermon. That was just the obligatory response to your having listed being a pack-day-smoker. Nothing good will come from that. Only you can eliminate that health risk.  That being said, the pain you describe doesn't really sound heart-related, for two reasons: one, it is very brief and fleeting, and two, its location is so far from the center (and can be on one side or the other at different times). This makes a cardiac cause fairly unlikely. The reason for the rapid heartrate following these episodes is most likely a startle reflex caused by the sudden onset of the pains. That just leaves us to figure out what's causing them.  Since these pains seem to be located in an area where the upper bronchial tree can refer pain, and also sounds somewhat pleuritic in nature, it may be that you're suffering from an irritation of the pleura, the protective membrane that surrounds the lungs. This pain is usually triggered by a deep breath, however.   The possibilities suggested by doctors all seem reasonable except for perimenopause, as 34 seems awfully early for that. The chostocondritis idea has possibilities but can easily be ruled in or out by pressing on the area in question. If you can provoke pain by moderate finger pressure in the general area of the pains then that's the likely cause. Also twisting of the upper body might have the same effect. Any pain that can be elicited by pressure or changing position is not cardiac related.   I can't help thinking that smoking may have something to do with this, though, if only secondarily.   There's still the anxiety angle, too. Although you deny stress and anxiety other than that generated by the symptoms, you also state your appetite is "gone" (and eating once a day I'd say that's an accurate assessment). Anxiety and/or panic attacks can actually kill one's appetite, cause non-specific chest pains, increase the heart rate and otherwise wreak havoc. In most such cases the patient denies a problem in precisely the area where it lies. It sounds strange but it's true.   Work on the smoking, as that will, as I've already said, make anything worse and ultimately cause you real, serious problems. Also open yourself up to the possibility of an anxiety-related problem. There are some really innocuous medications now available that can help a lot. And of course that's only one possibility.   I'm really doubting the perimenopause theory.   It seems you've ruled out any serious physical problems, so it might be worthwhile to take a closer look at anxiety as a cause. This is one of the sneakiest things we can encounter and the person so-affected is usually the last one to know.   Good luck to you and please stay in touch.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello asimkalim - While the symptoms you describe are highly atypical for cardiac pain, the pathway of radiation and the sweating argue for a medical rule-out of any sort of cardiac involvement. Chest pain which is clearly circumscribed is almost never heart-related, but you could have some sort of less serious structural problem. Costochondritis comes to mind first, but this rarely causes pain which radiates. The sweating and the hot extremities suggest a peripheral nervous response of some sort, but since the pain recurs and clearly causes you some concern, a visit to your primary physician seems a good way to allay your concerns and perhaps get the problem resolved at the same time.   Good luck to you and please keep us updated.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello MALICE - You have described one of the prominent features of both chronic generalized anxiety and panic disorder (GAD and PD). These pains are often physiologic in nature, not imagined, but are completely benign. The trouble is our awareness is trained on our heart's actions and our breathing when we suffer from anxiety (often a device to distract us from the real cause of our anxiety). Also, faulty breathing patterns that occur in anxious persons will eventually cause a variety of misleading symptoms including stabbing, sharp, rather random chest pains that further pull our attention toward that part of our body.   Since you have been diagnosed with panic disorder already, the challenge, for you, will be to learn to differentiate between symptoms which are attention-worthy and those which can be discarded at once. This isn't as easy as it might seem (as I'm sure you already know).   For our purposes here, the best thing I can tell you is that the pains, by nature and description are almost certainly benign, and they are also common in people with PD, often due to the above-mentioned faulty breathing patterns adopted by anxious people and also certain abnormal postures which sometimes become habitual for those same people.   I wonder how the Zoloft has worked for you so far as PD is concerned. Have you noticed a general improvement as yet? Sometimes the SSRI family of drugs work well, but are starting to fall out of favor since they can also provoke anxiety  in some people who are already prone to agitation. If you don't see significant improvement your doctor might consider changing over to something like clonazepam (Klonopin) which is a long-acting anti-anxiety and anti-seizure medication related to Xanax but long-acting and without many of the unwanted side-effects of Xanax.   Best of luck to you.

title: Chest pain worries narcoleptic patient
content: First, let me say Hello and thank you for reading my post. I appreciate the time you have taken to read what I have to say.  I am a 23 year old male who has been diagnosed with narcolepsy, asthma and infectious arthritis (caused by a very bad strep infection). Otherwise I am pretty healthy.  My family has a history of heart and vascular diseases on both sides of the family as well as diabetes (father), cancers (both grandfathers, father, grandmother and cousin), lupus (aunt) and allergies (ranging from mild to severely life threatening). My grandmother had her first CVA when she was about 35 and continued to ischemic strokes until she died at age 45. My brother has high blood pressure which is quite often as high as 237/180, even on medication. Mother has hypertension and my father did, too.  I am currently taking 300mg Provigil po qd, 50mcg Flonase po qd and Allegra 180mg po qd. For pain management I use ibuprofen 800mg prn po OR 650mg aspirin/195mg salicylamide prn po, but generally try to avoid NSAIDs unless necessary.  My primary concern is that I have narcolepsy, and besides Provigil, I have been on stimulants of all kinds for many years. 3 years ago, I suffered a massive strep infection (asymptomatic to full onset in less than 10 hours) which required short term hospitalization. Altogether, I have had 27 strep infections over 7 year period. After treatment for the last infection, I have not had any infections, but I was left with permanent joint pain. I was told to be watchful of heart related problems from the infection.  The problem I have is I have been getting sudden chest pain (on my left side, only in the area of the heart) in the last 8 months, which goes away within seconds or moments. It is a very deep, sharp pain which definitely feels internal and occurs sometimes when I stand up, move around, am physically active or sometimes when at rest.  At times this is accompanied by a pulsating feeling in my neck, around the area of the common carotid. It generally feels like it is a force traveling upwards, lasting a few seconds, and then subsides. I can feel the throbbing if I touch my neck when this happens.  Sometimes my pain radiates to my shoulder or armpit or shoulder blade, but is brief. I have gotten light headed at times when this happened esp. when standing up.  I had 2 EKGs, both normal, but pain was not present in either. I just wanted to know if this is something I should check out or if it is benign.  Thanks.
