author: sarta  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Dec 10, 2006 2:49 pm Location: new york city
title: heart palpitations, dizziness, fatigue
content: Hi,  I am 23, female, and I've always been very healthy, with slightly high blood pressure.  My mom and one of my sisters have heart murmers, and my dad takes medicine for high blood pressure.    This is what's bothering me:  My heart had been beating fast, and I'd been having palpitations, and what feel like flutters, and chest pains for about a week.  I also had a constant low fever (about 99.0-99.4).  I stopped having any caffeine after two days of this.  I saw a doctor finally a week ago, and had a EKG, which was normal.  He tested my thyroid hormones, and said they were normal too.  He gave me 10mg Inderal to take 3 times a day, and referred me to a cardiology clinic, which I haven't been to yet.  He told me he thinks I'm fine, and that this is probably all due to anxiety, but that I should get checked just to be sure.  I've been taking the inderal, which really helps the anxiety, but I've been feeling dizzy a lot of the time and my chest aches and I get out of breath when I exert myself even a little.  The center of my back, between my shoulder blades, feels sore.  I am a bit anxious about everything, so I've been very tense, which might be causing the back ache.  Also, for the last two days my stomach has been feeling very swollen and achy.  It hurts mostly along the bottom of my ribs, and especially right in the center if I press down a bit. I don't know if this is related or not.  I feel like my heart beats strangely when I lie down flat, and that it's better when I'm sitting up and even walking slowly.  I think I've been having trouble sleeping because of this.  Probably unrelated: I also have a firm lump, about 1cm across, that seems to be attached to my sternum.  It doesn't hurt unless I rub it a lot.  I forgot to mention it to my doctor.  I am just curious to know what might be going on, and whether it's anything I should be really worried about.  I don't have health insurance, but the clinic I was referred to is very affordable, though I don't know how long I will have to wait for an appointment.   Thanks for your advice in advance!

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The chest contains many organs, like the heart, lungs with its pleural covering, esophagus, muscles, ribs, tendons, and nerves. They all can be the source of the pain felt in the chest.  The swelling and chest pain may be related to costochondritis a condition in which there is inflammation where the ribs are attached to sternum. The swelling is usually tender.  In many cases it is of idiopathic origin. In others it results from direct trauma, aggressive exercise by a strain, or a prior upper respiratory tract infection with cough resulting in stretching and strain at the costochondral junction. You have mentioned that you have low grade fever in the last period, did you have any attack of respiratory tract infection and cough recently? .  Viral infection may cause both pain in the costochondral joint and palpitation as well. However, in case of chest pain, especially with family history, cardiac causes should be excluded. MVP (mitral vulvae prolapse is a common cause of palpitation and diagnose by echocardiography.  Sometimes chest pain is not originating from the chest itself; instead it is due to problems in the digestive tract. These problems include IBS, gastritis, gall bladder disease, GER. The pain and tenderness you feel at the lower sternum could be related to one of these causes.   Stress and anxiety alone can cause chest pain, epigastric pain and palpitations. They also aggravate the condition causes by most of the above diseases.  Hope this information is useful. Keep us updated. Best regards.

I sat there for about 5 more minutes and then started to notice my chest (equally both sides and down the front and backside of my arms and shoulders start to ache and had medium "pressure" feeling. (heart still racing intermittantly)I would say the pain of that was about a 3 or 4 - pretty mild to medium discomfort. I also had kind of referred pain to the back of my left side of neck and jawline - again pretty mild but noticibly something not right. I then decided to get up and head to the bathroom, felt hot and noticed after walking from my side of the bed (15 feet away) to the bedroom door I was completely exhausted and out of breath as if I had sprinted a entire block - I could not get a deep enough breath in and getting breath out seems labored as well. I felt just like when you are recooperating from a surgery and have been sent home - you think you can get up and move afterward and then all of a sudden your blood pressure drops and you almost faint... it was very similar to this feeling but with serious heart racing - so fast that it took my breath away. I decided to stay sitting up in bed or laying flat for the next two hours and then seemed ok. Everything was normal except the ECG. The doctor before I was sent to the other hospital gave me two baby asprin and apple juice "just in case" before I was told to drive over there.   I was sent home and still experiencing some very mild chest discomfort (to the touch and really mild pressure) I can almost ignore it .. it is so mild... my blood pressure when I arrived was 97 / 90 and pulse was ? per minute. BP was taken again 45 minutes later and it had gone up to 100 / 65 and bpm was at 80.   In addition to the bL reading and the Poor R-wave Progression these were the findings that I can read and translate for you ...   Rate 55 Normal Heart rythm  Normal P Axis  PR 128  QRSD 74  QT 377  QTc 369   Axis:  P 59  QRS 83  T 43   Poor R-wave Progression shows ...  1 R < .15 or 2 R's < .2 (<----(the rest of this number is cut off by paper ending)   I can clearly see in the aVF area on the ECG that a rather dark line (blip) that looks short but erratic up and down. And Also on the aVR as well but not so erratic. I can't read these ECG's or know what they mean but it appears I have a normal rythm on the bottom "baseline string" at the bottom of page but the rest is quite irregular and faint in certain area's with changes in the extra bumps after the initial strikes for each beat in those areas of aVF and aVR.   NOW....   I know that this could be nothing more than a case of bad indigestion - I am not totally paniced however when I got home I had a jarred memory from the experienc ethat warrants some more investigation I beleive and that is that several yaers ago (in the mid 80's approx. 21 years old) I went through a battery of tests for a then current illness and I had remebered being asked if I had ever been diagnosed with a "heart murmur" or "Irregular Heartbeat" in the past. I said ??? no Idea... never followed up on it and it was never discussed again. I feel that if for no other reason I should have one done to check this possibilty of the congenital irregular beats that run in my family and to just get the question of this off my "chest" so to speak.  Please help me with this - the first doctor I saw seemed very concerned (I am also a light smoker) (yes I will be quitting on New years day) and so I am slightly confused as to the different opinions I have been told. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: You've been very thorough in collecting and sharing your clinical findings! That's a big help, as is your very thorough description of the problem, as well as your family history.   Now then: there are several different facets to what you have presented here. First, you do have a very positive family history for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and possibly Heavy Chain Disease as well. Oddly, your own blood work reveals a very healthy young woman with only a slightly elevated LDL level, with all other cholesterol components looking very good. That's something you might want to work on, but could also be a fluke, so should be repeated. Other than that, nothing much looks wrong on paper. While your EKG is not "normal" (low voltage in the frontal leads is very common in women, and "poor R-wave progression" is a very non-specific finding, especially in light of everything else being fine). I think you can feel pretty good about that.   Now then, the episode you described is quite striking for a number of reasons. First, it starts out sounding like a fairly typical panic attack, which, in the properly predisposed subject, could be set off by any number of things including a small amount brandy, as that stuff is potent and is great at causing vasodilation and flushing, as well as some of the symptoms you described. Since you are an infrequent drinker, the effect could have been amplified. So there's one part; however, the incident progressed to more concrete symptoms which would seem to follow the textbook description of Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS). With your major family history and the episode as you describe it, you were certainly wise to get yourself checked out. Women frequently tend to have atypical ACS symptoms however, and yours were quite textbook - up to a point. Where they veered off, and this is an important issue, is in that you describe point tenderness in your "chest area and tops of shoulders." This would suggest something other than a heart-related problem, as point tenderness and pain on body movement is usually related to some musculoskeletal issue and almost never to the heart.  While I find a lot of things in your very complete report to point away from the heart and more toward something emotional or even GI or orthopedically-related, the fact that your symptoms at the height of the episode, your family history, and the fact that women in the United States often still do tend to be dismissed by doctors as over-reactors, all warrant a further investigation into what happened. A family history like yours is one of the highest-priority risk factors (as you obviously are aware). While your acute episode does sound like a mixture of possible cardiac symptoms and anxiety-related ones, you quite rightly pointed to the "sense of impending doom" which many ACS sufferers experience. Then again, this also occurs in every panic attack. This clouds the picture, because as with most potential heart problems, the patient usually will feel a good deal of anxiety until and unless he or she can be reassured that the heart is fine, and that is a totally reasonable kind of anxiety, even if it does only serve to muddy the clinical picture. (Anxiety can cause so many cardiac-type symptoms that a majority of people seen in US ERs wind up having had acute anxiety or a panic attack rather than an actual coronary event, but almost all will have had some anxiety regardless).   Based on the description of your espisode, and setting aside the number of mitigating factors (such as point tenderness and some vague symptoms mixed in with the more concrete ones) and your very positive family history, I would suggest you insist on a full workup including nuclear scan stress test and echocardiogram, in order to allow you to put your mind at ease. Were it not for the family history I would probably be more inclined to lean toward an emotional basis for this, but because of that history there is no way I would ignore that potential risk, regardless of all the things I've been able to scratch off the list here. It would seem almost a common sense move to want to evaluate you despite your youth and the fact that anyone with such a positive family history would have to have some possibly hidden concerns about heart disease (and rightly so).   My hunch is that your heart is fine. Medical decisions ought not be based on hunches, however. For your own peace of mind and out of deference to common sense and the symptoms at the center of your primary episode, I would, were I you, pressure my doctor to refer for a comprehensive cardiac workup with nuclear scan stress test and echo. Everything else seems to have been done, but your peace of mind is certainly worth that much extra effort.  Good luck to you. I'm betting you're fine, but no one with a family history like yours should take a pass on being as sure as you can be.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: What you have described is a very common phenomenon in most people, and especially during pregnancy. The "skipped" beats, Premature Atrial Contractions (PACs) are the most benign of all irregular heartbeats, and one of the most common, alongside Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs). Almost everyone has some of these from time to time, and they can feel strange enough to be quite alarming, but they are almost never a true medical concern. In pregnancy, especially, they can become more frequent, because the growing fetus is taking up a lot of room in your abdomen and can cause other internal structures to crowd the heart. This is a lot like what happens after eating a large meal. Between the fact that the heart "doesn't like to be touched" and, in the case of pregnancy, there being higher levels of some hormones which can also make the heart's muscle irritable, one is quite likely to have some episodes of palpitations such as you have described. In an otherwise healthy heart these have virtually no significance. The are also not diagnostic of a heart problem in themselves, so doctors do often tend to treat them cavalierly, forgetting the emotionas they can stir up, especially anxiety over the heart's behavior, and during pregnancy those emotions are often amplified anyway.   The bottom line is your doctor is correct in his analysis, but what I hear most frequently is that the doctor didn't take the time to explain what these sensations are, why they happen, and why they are normal.   You sound like a very healthy young woman who will no doubt give birth to a very healthy baby in time. Stopping caffeine is always worth a try when these "skipped" (actually premature or early) beats become bothersome or anxiety-producing. Sometimes it helps, as caffeine is a stimulant and all stimulants can, in some people, help trigger these beats.   Otherwise you sound absolutely fine. Try to enjoy this time and congratulations on your upcoming blessed event!

title: Elevated heart rate
content: Hi guys   im 18 years old and in good health. Since yesterday ive been having really strange symptoms with my pulse. Basically when I adminster the test myself I get normal readings in between 60-100. However when I used my grandfather's blood pressure monitoring machine I get weird resultrs. First of all I want to admit that I am a hypochondriac and I worry really easily about my health and since yesterday ive been obsessed with my heart. On his machine I get readings above 100...105,103 and around that. However its inconsistent. Ill check once and itll say 120. Ill check 2 minutes later it'll be in the 90s. Check again it'll be in the 80s. Then itll go back over a 100 again. Im a bit freaked out over this. I don't have anyother symptoms...My blood pressure is normal...And I can move\run around fine...Could it be that my anxiety leads to a rapid heart rate?   Any comments would be greatly appreciated..   Thank you
posted_time: Post  by john_33 » Sat Dec 16, 2006 6:46 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I'm presuming the numbers you are giving are your heart rate.  Normal heart rates for your age are 60-100.  Being slightly above this is normal, especially when your anxious.  I suspect that your rapid heart rate is a little "white coat syndrome".    It's very common for people to have slightly elevated heart rates and blood pressures at their doctor's office because of a little anxiety.  If your not having any other symptoms and only notice that your pulse is elevated when your checking it, then I would not be too worried about it.  If you notice it is consistently up and does not seem normal to you, you can always discuss it with your doctor and get a full examination.  Hope this helps.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Dec 16, 2006 9:37 pm

content: Hello i am a 28 year old male, and a i have a question about possible cardiac pain.  here is a brief history of my health.  Back in 2001 i was diagnosed with Diabetes, never really took it seriously so i would say i had about 4-5 years of uncontrolled diabetes.  Well back in september i was doing some reading up on diabetes because i decided it was about time for me to get educated in the matter and change how i was treating it, or not treating if for that matter.    i went to the md back in september for a check up weight was 261..blood pressure was high 155/82.  md started me on lisinopril 10 mg once a day, and back on metforming 500mg one in morning one in evening.  i have since dramatically changed my lifestyle..eating totally different, getting moderate exercise  (20-30min) almost everyday on the exercise bike.  i have brought my blood sugar readings down to usually 120-125 in the am and 105-115 in the evening.  oh i also forgot to mention that when i was diagnosed diabetic i weighed 311lbs...cholesterol back when diagnosed was total 210 LDL 129 HDL 32 triglycerides 244..now when i went this past september they did another lipid test and my cholesterol levels were now total 173 LDL 113 HDL 36 triglyserides 121 my A1C was 8.5...  Well since changing everythign i am now down to 235lbs, and i am due for another lipid test in january pretty excited for that i want to see where i am at..oh any my bp was now down to 127/72 i beleive it was in november check up...  now getting to my question now that you know about my history, every once in a while i will get not really a pain i don't know how to describe it, but a very quick fast throb that last for maybe 2 seconds i would say it is located about 5 inches under my neck and 3 inches from my arm pit on the left side of my chest.. it is very fleeting. sometimes it can be felt into my back...now i also have a little history of heart disease in my family my grandfather passed away of a heartattack at 73 and my uncle at 57..i don't get shortness of breath nor tightness or pressure in my chest.  i was out shoveling the drive inthe cold today and got a little lightheaded..are any of these indications of heart disease or cardiac pain i am feeling in my chest.  i am very paranoid about this now due to the diabetes... please help me...  thanks  Chuck G.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I am glad that you have been able to deal with many of your risk factors. By doing so you have significantly reduced the likelihood of getting heart disease in the future hopefully.  The pain you are describing is not characteristic of cardiac pain. Characteristic cardiac pain has the following features:  It is often described as central chest tightness or heaviness which is brought on by exertion and relieved by rest. It may radiate to the arms, the neck, jaw or teeth. Associated symptoms include dyspnea, nausea, sweatiness, faintness.  Precipitating factors Exercise  Emotion  Cold weather  Heavy meals   Pain that is unlikely to be of cardiac origin is typically well localized, sharp, pricky, lancinating type sometimes lasting less than 15 seconds. It can be aching type too but mostly will be aggravated on deep inspiration and coughing. Patient will be able to localize it with the tip of her finger.  Pain that is localized just below left nipple is almost NEVER of cardiac origin.  Please understand that given the limitations of the internet I cannot properly assess or exclude the presence of any serious heart condition. Call your doctor and report your symptoms to him.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: First the reassuring thing-pain that is worse with a deep breath is not related to the heart, so this is not heart attack pain.  The pain you describe is consistent with a few different things.  First, pleurisy can cause such pain.  The pleura are the linings of the lungs, heart, inside chest wall, etc.  Occasionally an area may get inflamed producing pain.  It is worse with deep breaths because it causes the inflamed pleura to be moved.  Generally this will heal on its own, although anti-inflammatory medications can be helpful if severe.    A second possibility is a syndrome called Precordial Catch Syndrome.  This can cause sudden, stabbing feeling pain with deep breaths, as if the diaphragm or lung is caught on something.  This also tends to resolve on its own.  Please keep in mind that I am not examining you and making an accurate diagnosis over the internet is nearly impossible.  As such, if the pain is worsening or not getting better you should have a true evaluation.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: A few PVC's are considered normal as long as they don't compromise function.  Generally normal PVC's should lessen with increased heart rate.  When you felt your heart racing, did is suddenly start (as if a light switch had been flipped on) or did it gradually increase in rate.  Also, did it stop abruptly or gradually slow down.  Sudden starts and stops can be associated with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) although a rate of 160 is on th slow side for this type of tachycardia.    One of the most common causes of what you are describing is an anxiety attack. Often this is accompanied by a feeling of dread.  It can be normal to feel your heart beating if it is beating hard.  However, if the symptoms continue, or if they are becoming worrisome to you you should have them evaluated by a physician.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sun Dec 10, 2006 10:22 pm

author: babyblueeyes156  Guest Posts: 25 Joined: Sat Dec 09, 2006 10:00 pm
title: [no title]
content: It started all at once and ended just as quickly. I wasn't under any anxiety at the time it happened. Just wanted to make sure it was normal cause it didn't feel so normal!!! Thanks for helping.
posted_time: Post  by babyblueeyes156 » Tue Dec 12, 2006 8:03 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Sudden starting and stopping of rapid heart beating can be an indicator of a dysrhythmia such as SVT.  I would recommend talking to your doctor about it if it happens again.  You may need to have a holter monitor or an event monitor to catch the episodes.  A simple ECG is a good place to start, though.  Your doctor can look for conditions such as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome that can predispose you to SVT with an ECG.  If the ECG is normal then consider the holter or other event monitor.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The first step is to assess the presence of risk factors for cardiac disease. The presence of less risk factors makes heart disease less likely. Age (the incidence increases with age and is higher in those above 50).  Males are more prone than females (especially premenopausal women). Males are 5 times more prone to develop the disease at the age of 50.  Serum cholesterol and lipids: A ratio of LDL to HDL of greater than 4:1 increases the risk dramatically. Conversely, a higher HDL level seems to offer protection. Serum cholesterol levels should be kept below 200mg/dL.  Smoking: increases the incidence by 60%.  Hypertension: whether systolic or diastolic tends to increase the risk.  Diabetes mellitus: is known to increase the incidence of IHD both in males and females.  Family history: a familial predisposition is known to exist and is in part due to inheritence of the above risk factors.  Oral contraceptives is associated with an increased incidence of myocardial infarction.  Gout, Type A personality, premature arcus corneae, obesity, hypertriglyceridemia and diagonal ear lobe crease have all been reported to increase the risk of developing ischemic heart disease.  Characteristic cardiac pain has the following features:  It is often described as central chest tightness or heaviness which is brought on by exertion and relieved by rest. It may radiate to the arms, the neck, jaw or teeth. Associated symptoms include dyspnea, nausea, sweatiness, faintness.  Precipitating factors Exercise  Emotion  Cold weather  Heavy meals   Pain that is unlikely to be of cardiac origin is typically well localized, sharp, pricky, lancinating type sometimes lasting less than 15 seconds. It can be aching type too but mostly will be aggravated on deep inspiration and coughing. Patient will be able to localize it with the tip of her finger.  Pain that is localized just below left nipple is almost NEVER of cardiac origin.  Chest pain in young women is commonly associated with conditions such as mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic valve disease (such as mitral stenosis), anxiety and depression, neuromusculoskeletal conditions (the pain is very well localized and tender to the touch), gastrointestinal (esophageal reflux, esophageal spasm and peptic ulcer disease), or lung conditions (pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, pleurisy, pneumothorax).  As you can see chest pain in a young female has lots of reasons. Most of the time they are not of cardiac origin. A thorough clinical examination, appropriate investigations, and reassurance will go a long way in resolving this issue.  Please understand that given the limitations of the internet I cannot exclude the presence of any serious heart condition.  My opinion is for you to seek another opinion if you are still complaining of chest pain. Your palpitations are most likely to be caused by sinus arrhythmia.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Pain related to ingestion of fatty food is usually associated with gall bladder disease.   The pain is usually chronic dull aching or alternatively, acute constant episodes of sharp pain in the right hypochondriac area. It may present as pain in the epigastrium.   Sometimes it is associated with vomiting, fever, local tenderness and rigidity, and your physician may be able to palpate gall bladder mass.  If this is a recurring problem you should have it properly evaluated since this is not possible here given the limitations of the internet.  Best regards,

title: fyi
content: HI GT1924:  You have a lot of misc things going on.   I'm sure you have heard what I am going to tell you before.  First, if you saw your GP, obviously he/she didn't think there was any serious heart condition.  Heart conditions don't wait until you get insurance.  If you have one, you deal with it NOW, not 6 months from now.  My advice would be to quit smoking,  try to get some gentle (such as walking) exercise.   Some information you left out which would be helpful is how much you weigh, and do your ankles swell?  If so, when?  Do they ever not swell?  Do you have varicose veins or is this red thing on your ankle something new?   Obviously you've seen your Dr and he/she doesnt think you have any emergency situations, but its very difficult to discuss so many issues without a lot of information and or seeing you.  Having your blood pressure taken once is useless, take it over a week, and keep a log, same with pulse.  Are you on any medications?  As you can see, this isn't a question with a simple answer.  I really think you should make a list of all the issues that concern you and have a very candid discussion with your doctor insurance or not, so that your mind can be put at ease.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi jinkus, There are a variety of causes of the sensation of "skipped/gained beats" both cardiac and noncardiac in origin. If you have had an evaluation by a cardiologist an there is no underlying cardiac anomaly, a noncardiac cause of course should be considered. Increased levels of stress, anxiety, caffiene, certain over the counter medications, electrolyte imbalances, endocrine dysfunction, etc., etc., may cause symptoms. I would suggest an evaluation by your physician, along with some diagnostics, ie., labwork, to rule out any other causative factors. If an etiology for the palpitations can not be found, reducing stress levels, and episodes that trigger anxiety would also be helpful. Congratulations on stopping smoking by the way! Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: Racing Heart in Athlete
content: I am a certified athletic trainer at a high school in Georgia and have a 17 year old, male, tri-sport athlete that has a condition that no cardiologist has been able to produce or detect on various test.  There is no family history of rapid or irregular heart beats and the athlete is on no current medication.  This athlete randomly gets a racing heart with beats over 140bpm and has very high blood pressure (>150/100).  He has been seen by a cardiologist and has been cleared to participate in all sporting events.  The cardiologist has told this athlete that when this occurs all he should do is lay down and wait approximately 5 minutes once it stops before returning to play.  I am just wondering if anyone has seen any cases like this and if so is this a condition that should be closley monitored in fear of something bad happening.    Thank you for your time in looking at this situation!!!
posted_time: Post  by abodie24 » Thu Feb 16, 2006 9:03 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi abodie24, I would be quite concerned over this childs symptoms. Generally speaking, in athletic persons, heart rate and blood pressures are typically lower than normal. In all honesty, in my opinion, advising one to just lay down and rest until symptoms subside, without determination of the causative factor is unwise. Have any other medical or psychological conditions, ie, diabetes, anxiety or panic attacks, etc., been ruled out? Are there any other symptoms, aside from the racing heartbeat and elevated blood pressure? Has he been evaluated by a pediatric cardiology specialist? Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Onelildarlin2u, Inflammation of the chest wall may cause significant pain. Pain also triggers elevations in heart rate and blood pressure. If only an EKG was completed, no xray, nor labwork, I would strongly suggest that you have a re-evaluation. These diagnostics should have been (and should be) completed as well. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi SSC, There are various things that may produce symptoms of chest pain both benign and cardiac in origin. Any complaint of chest pain should be evaluated by a physician to rule out a cardiac origin. Benign(noncardiac in origin) causes of chest pain are, for example, anxiety, stress, GERD, respiratory problems (Asthma, bronchitis, pneumonia, pleurisy), etc. Pain usually doesn't change with activity. Regardless of the causative factor, a cardiac etiology should be ruled out by a physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: lasting chest pain
content: I'm 28, male, 6'0, 240lbs.(so ~50 over), cholest: 200, hdl: 140, ldl:40, BP 140/80, never smoked, sedentary life, a lot of stress, taking Xanax now and then. Small family cardiac history.  5 weeks ago after 19 hours in an airplane, next day I started having shortness of breath mostly in the 2nd half of the day, regardless of doing exercise of not. It doesn’t correlate with exercise or meals.  Went to a cardiologist, still and stress EKG/BP/echo looked OK, still and stress EKG/BP/echo OK (except 'borderline functional capacity' !?), didn't feel any pain/shortness of breath while running on the treadmill. Blood tests OK (including D-Dimer <200). CXR OK. He said it's probably GERD, gave me few pills for GERD, took those for 2 weeks, started also taking 81mg aspirin and Xanax on my own, no good.  I can't properly fall asleep laid on my back, feel like suffocating sometimes, pinches/aches in my left arm/shoulder, sometimes palpitations/heat waves sometimes, cold sweats, chest pain is still diffuse and lasts for hours, 2nd half of the day. During the morning usually only a light shortness of breath is present.  Went again to the cardiologist few days ago, did only still EKG, looked OK, BP OK as well, no clues.  I also read that angina usually doesn't last for hours. The pain still lasts for hours, same for shortness of breath.  Pericarditis? Pleurisy? Aorta/tri-valve obstruction? author: Deby Moore  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Feb 22, 2006 5:30 pm
title: sudden increases in B/P
content: I am a 50 year old female.  I have been trying to find out what is wrong with me for the past 2 years.  I have seen my family doctor, endocrine doctor, have had head MRI, chest CT, cardiac stress test, and numerous lab tests.  I keep feeling worse and no one has found an answer to what is going on.  My hx is this, 4 years ago I was dx with essential tremors, (although I tremor at rest and with activity) and am on no medication for this as any I tried never helped with the tremors, but only made me sleepy.  The tremors came on suddenly 2 months after being struck in the face, and suffered a blow to my rt shoulder and left upper chest from a pt where I worked.  2 years ago I began feeling very fatigued, this started in the winter time.  When summer came anytime I went outside to do anything I would start sweating profusly, my face became extremely red and I felt as if all my strenght was drained from me.  This occurred all summer, then when the weather became cooler I noticed the sweating decreased, but the fatigue remained.  Lab work done showed I was postmentalpausal.  I only have 1 ovary and would monitor my levels and 1 1/2 years earlier I was normal.  So of course everone said I was having  hot flashes.  Except they only came on with activity.  The follow spring a cardiac stress test was done and I was told it was normal, a chest CT showed nodulas in my right lung (has been repearted with no change) and a slight increase in size in accending aorta, told it was ok.  Head MRI was normal except it said something about some markings that could suggest MS.  This last summer sx returned with the sweating and fatigue, sever enough I went outside very little.  A year ago I developed a pain in my upper chest on the lt side.  AT times it is a deep pain that will go into my back at times or a burning feeling.  My lt arm will also hurt with numbness in my last 2 fingers, swelling, dicoloration at times.  At times after using my arm I will also get numbness on the lt side of my neck and face.  I started watching my b/p last year and noticed anytime I started feeling bad, brought on with miminal physical activity, that my b/p would be elevated.  As high as 180/110, then return to my normal of 110/70 with in an hour or so.  Prior to doing anything my b/p was also in the range.  I get palpations and feel wweak.  It has been noted on my last dr vist that my b/p in my rt arm was 126/78, but in my lt. it was 80/p.  Also any time a b/p or lab is done in my lt arm it causes my marm to hurt, not alittle, but like someone is cutting my arm off.  This was done by the endo dr. who has refered me to a cardiologist, who I have not seen yet.  I am very concerned with what is going on with me, I am not able to do much of anything without becoming ill.  2 years ago I dug a 100 ft, 2 ft deep drainage ditch by hand, and back filled it with gravel, now I can't dig a hole to plant a tree.  Am I headed in the right direction with the caridologist?  Thanks for any information.  Deby

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi BrynAlbee, A productive cough of yellow, green, etc sputum typically indicates an infection is present and generally speaking, is treated with a course of antibiotic therapy. Certain over the counter medications should not be taken by individuals who have asthma. When purchasing over the counter medications it's wise to consult with the Pharmacist to assure safety. Bronchospasms may cause symptoms in which you describe and are typically treated with a bronchodialator to decrease episodes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Angelheart  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Feb 24, 2006 12:37 pm
title: Intense Heart Pounding Tachycardia
content: I am a 48 year old female. Beginning last March I began to feel my heart racing on occasion and had difficulty talking and breathing at the same time during these episodes. A couple of months later it seemed to have worsened because out of the blue my heart would start pounding so fast and so hard it felt like it would jump right out of my chest. And I would experience pain in the center of my chest near my heart. These intense pounding sensations started at first only occasionally but soon they became more frequent and would start for no reason through out the day. I would estimate that my heart was beating at well over 200 beats per minute (kind of like a jack hammer) for roughly 15- 30 seconds each time I had an episode and it was so hard that I could feel it all the way up my throat and into my ears. This really scared me!   I went to the doctor because I also suspected that in addition to my heart problem I was diabetic because of my family history  and my symptoms of night sweats and extreme fatigue, and wanted to be tested. The tests showed that I am indeed diabetic and the dctor put me on Metaglip 25/500mgs. After trying several BP meds that caused severe physical reactions, my doctor put me on Verelan PM 300 mgs. I also take 25mgs of Hydrochlorothyzide for the edema in my feet and ankles caused by the Verelan. This has stopped the intense pounding, but I still feel my heart beating fast on occasion.    I was born with a heart murmur I was told was harmless and had lazy eye and I am blind in my left eye. I was diagnosed with Optic Nerve Atrophy in both eyes, with the optic nerve in the left eye being so shrivled it is the cause of the blindness from birth. The right side is not as severe.  I recently went to a new physician. During my visit I asked her if I should have had any kind of testing done on my heart. When she discovered that I had never had any tests she immediately did and EKG in her office. My heart beat was 101 even with the medication I have been taking, so the doctor sent me for an Echocardiogram.   I just had the Echo done and won't get the results until next week, but I am curious about a couple of things.   The technician seemed to spend a long time focusing on the lower left side of my heart and I wonder what that might indicate?   How high is too high for my heart to beat, especially since I'm already taking medication that is supposed to control this?  I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia about 3-4 years ago, but now wonder if this fatigue could have been the diabetes. And could these heart symptoms I have be contributing to this fatigue because I still have days where I  am extremely exhausted?  Thank you for looking at my post.
posted_time: Post  by Angelheart » Fri Feb 24, 2006 1:51 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am

content: Hi Angelheart, Have you had any other diagnostics aside from the EKG, and Echo, ie, stress test, cardiac catherization, etc.? A heart rate of 101 beats per minute at rest would most likely indicate that it is not well controlled with the current medication regimen. I hope you have had a follow up, etc. with your physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Intense heart pounding tachycardia
content: Dear AngelHeart,  100 beats per minute is the cutoff for tachycardia.  Your blood pressure medication can cause slowing of the heart rate. This does not necessarily mean that your heart rate is actually high and your blood medication is making it slower than it should.  The feeling of fatigue can actually be caused by your blood pressure medication as a direct side effect or if your blood pressure gets really low especially that you are taking hydrocholorothiazide at the same time which is a diuretic and can cause dehydration and dehydration can lead to fatigue. Fibromyalgia is a known cause of fatigue as well.  From the description of your tachycardia episodes, you might need to be evaluated by a cardiologist.  In addition to heart causes, tachycardia may be caused by thyroid disease and disturbance in the blood electrolytes. Blood electrolytes disturbance can be caused by hydrocholorothiazide as well.  If you never had your blood tested, i would suggest that you have a thyroid function test and blood chemistry test.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Thu May 11, 2006 2:24 pm

title: echocardiogram

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  Tricuspid insufficiency 1/4 means trivial tricuspid valve regurgitation. Tricuspid valve is the valve controlling blood flow between the right atrium and the right ventricle.   Trivial to mild tricuspid regurgitation is normal, physiological and present in more than 40 % of the general population. It is not an abnormality neither requires any treatment.  Dr. A. Madia

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi rileysales, If your symptoms were essentially nonexistent while using the medication cymbalta, in my opinion, I would be more inclined to consider that your symptoms were anxiety/stress related. However, you could certainly ask your physician for a referral to a cardiologist to rule out any cardiac origin for your symptoms. This will be beneficial to you even if no cardiac origin is found in at the very least alleviating your fears that a physical disorder is present. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: test reliability
content: Hi!!  I'm a 49 year old female who is having strange symptoms.  After telling my doctor that i was having a pain on my upper, left side an EKG was done.  The EKG showed I had had a heart attack at some time.  My doctor did not believe it was true.  he sent me for a stress test which was normal other than a slight buildup of plaque in the right artery.  He did refer me to a cardiologist.  Again, an EKG was done which also showed a heart attack.  I was then given an echocardiogram which was normal and did not show any damage.  Cardiologist said I was fine.  I continue to have the pain.  It seems to be in sync with an ache in my back exactly opposite of the pain in my chest.  I've also had fluttering in my chest with a weird feeling coming over me.  Heartburn has also increased.  How reliable are the tests I've had done?  Should I go back to the doctor and ask for more to be done?  Both parents have heart diasease.
posted_time: Post  by kcteach » Sat Feb 25, 2006 11:17 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi kcteach, Even though the EKG appeared abnormal, generally speaking when an evaluation for cardiac damage related to a heart attack, the cardiologist considers all of the diagnostic information as a group rather than depending on one specific diagnostic study. However, taking into consideration that you are still experiencing symptoms, have a family history of heart disease, and have the development of arterial plaque, additional diagnostics may be indicated. Has there been any mention regarding a cardiac catherization? If there has not I would suggest inquiring about this procedure as well as a re-evaluation. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  Theoretically speaking yes you still do need Stress test even though the Echo is normal. Because Echo shows state of the valves, chambers, pumping power etc. Only if some damage has resulted from lack of blood supply, it will show.  Whereas stress test or stress thallium will show lack of blood supply to the heart even before any damage is done. In this sense it can "predict" future heart attacks or anginal pains.  Your clinical description though does not fit into the cardiac type of pain though. You have not stated your age, habits, (smoking etc).   But always, to evaluate a case of chest pain Echo and a stress EKG/thallium done in tandem are more informative and accurate.   Dr Apurva Madia

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kalema, Palpitations are frequently described as skipping, fluttering, sudden racing, etc. Palpitaions may be caused from numerous conditions, cardiac in origin, stress, caffiene, etc. However, palpitations including episodes of chest pain, regardless of age, should prompt an evaluation by your physician to identify the causative factor. author: matt_briggs  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Feb 20, 2006 12:36 pm
title: Feel Heart Beat/Stomach/Chest
content: ok, for starters:  20 years old; male 6'3, 155 lbs. (thin) no previous health history no family history no allergies or med's.. no surgeries or diagnosis smoked for 3 years; pack every 2 days, quit 2 months ago  ok.. in january, i had a bad cold, coughing all the time mainly and stuffy nose.. mom used to wake me up and give me water because i would cough in my sleep and not know it.. anyways, i kind of left it "untreated" until about 4 or 5 days before it passed.. or so i thought it passed..  about 2 days after it passed, i started experiencing chest pains everytime i took a deep breath.. then, about 2 days after this, i was talking to my girlfriend on the phone while driving, and as i was just about to pull onto my street, i had to hang up the phone on her, and it was like i had a panic attack or SOMETHING, of some sort, it came out of NOWHERE..   i could barely move because it would be very uncomfortable and would hurt if i moved too much, i was lightheaded, short of breath, pale, and my heart rate was through the roof.. avg. 125 beats per minute while resting..  i called 911 because i have never experienced anything like that before and it scared me, no idea what it could have been.. but when i got to the hospital, it started to subside, and my chest pain started to die down as well as my heart rate and so on... but from that day forward ive been having minor chest pain here and there throughout the day, everyday; i went to emerg once and had an x-ray done because it was mainly pain on my right side, and x-rays were negative, they said it is probably a strained muscle from coughing so much.. ok, thats fine.... and its not that my heart beats fast, because it doesnt, usually about 70 beats a minute.. but i can almost CONSTANTLY feel my heart beating, even in my wrist and sometimes my neck when doing streneous work.. and i can see my chest move as well as my shirt, almost everytime it look for it, and i am CONSTANTLY thinking about my heart beating hard.. i sometimes have to toss and turn to get a comfortable position in bed, where i can barely feel my heart beat so i can fall asleep.. i have also had trouble in recent weeks making a complete and full bowel movement.. although i have been VERY gassy, and it does help relieve some chest/abdominal pain..  i have been to my family doctor.. she thinks it is withdrawl symptoms from quitting smoking and anxiety/stress.. she listend to my heart and said it sounds "great".. no murmurs, no skipped or extra beats, nothing.. and it may very well be.. but it is constant, everyday and is getting VERY annoying..   i finally got up yesterday, and went to the emergency with my girlfriend, waited for 5 hours, finally got in to see the doctor.. i explained everything to her, she hooked me up to an EKG, a heart monitor AND took my blood work... waited for an hour.. my girlfriend and I watched my BPM the entire time.. varied between 56 and 75 and my blood pressure is around 125/75 or something like that, which i am told is good.. when the results all came back, nothing wrong! everything looked great.. all my cardiac was good, the EKG and the blood work turned up fine.. he said he believes it is withdrawl from smoking as well... but im not buying it at all! these are not usual symptoms for quitting cold turkey are they???   so my MAIN concerns are, what is causing my "awareness" or my heart beats, mainly when sitting or laying down or stand still, my occassionaly chest pain, varies between right and left side, only lasts for a second or 2.. and my bowel movement problem?? is it just anxiety/stress and withdrawl symptoms? please i need an experts advice! thanks so much!   Matt

author: RichardC  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Tue Jan 11, 2005 7:09 pm Location: United Kingdom
title: [no title]
content: Hi, I'm a 20 year old male. I've posted in this forum before about heart flutters and palpitations and I read your post and can relate in some ways to what you're going through.  The similarities between us are quite the same! I posted on here just over a year ago and I still think about my heart beats, possibily because I let stress get the better of me which isnt always a good thing! The typical factor to rid yourself of this is trying to get your mind off it. I find engrossing yourself in something you find interesting will releave a large part of it. If not all of it! Overtime you may see the sense that you shouldn't have actually been worrying about it at all, and that life is too short to think about it! (As with many of peoples panics). It has worked for me, but my lifestyle just has just not yet accomodated it full time.  Just briefly to explain my situation, and I'm here to help, but I've recently become more concerned about my heart and am likely going to do the EKG similar to you (Just on the safe side). I have had this on and off for about 3 years now, with palpitations and slight to noticable flutters over the period. Palpitations are a rapid increase in heart rate. They cause the heart to beat strongly in your chest and in most cases don't last long before the hearts natural pace returns to normal. In my case, right away. These can be due to drug stimulants such as coffee, stress and the like. My palpitations in particular were due to extreme stress that I exerted on my body, possibly 100% mentally, provoking anxiety which then lead to the extreme levels of stress which affected my heart. I feel now that I am doing it once again. Recently however I have felt more prolonged irregular beats, upto 5 seconds. So yes, in my case I need to just relax a lot and I have also been told that it is connected with stress. My one concern is that I don't want to end up doing anything damaging to my heart in the long term!  If you'd like to find out more about the situation I suffered above you might find my post/replies quite useful in revealing a few answers. http://www.doctorslounge.com/cardiology ... -3153.html  Try to ignore the bit at the end! That was a concern I had, that I believe was quite irrational!  However, I am trying to focus on you. Judging from what you have said I would most likely say that you suffered a palpitation. This is what happened to you in the car when on the phone to your girlfriend. You could have felt a sudden gripping or contraction that lead to the fast onset of beats? Or perhaps it just came on, I don't know as I am not you! :) The good thing I have been told, is that these are nothing to worry about. Obviously if they kept happening it is probably based on your current lifestyle or outlook on what is possibily stressing you? I don't know, you didnt say if you were stressed! However, you said you think about your heart beat all the time? Well, it is likely, just as I do, you're anxious and dwelling on these which is causing you to notice it WAY more than normal. Being in your 20s, its a stress!! I know!! I am 20!! A lot of it is made up in your mind. That doesnt mean you need any psychological help, it just means that you are frightened of the unknown, as I can be a lot of the time, and therefore force yourself to become paranoid.   As I am sure the doctor will say, I doubt very much in this young stage of your life that smoking had any lasting affect on your heart. I am no professional, merely someone who has experienced the same as you. I really would like to hear more from you about how you're getting on because sometimes finding common ground with people can help a lot in talking the problem you face over.  P.S - I don't think that smoking has or had any effect on you. Anxiety in my view can be a more powerful drug than any stimulant if it is pushed that way. I'd really like to know if you suffered from any stress prior to your querry:)  I hope I can be of some use!  RichardC

title: Chest pain for 5 months
content: I'm a 25 year old male from Miami, FL. I've been pretty healthy all my life.  Only surgery was to remove a nose polyp in 2005.  I've always had gas problems, and have had some tests done in the past including a sigmoidoscopy in 2000, all negative.  Well, starting in October of 2005 I began having pains in the left side of my chest.  It would come and go.  I went and had an EKG and an ultrasound (ECO) done.  While I was waiting for the results I had a panic attack and ended up in the ER.  They did some tests and said it was anxiety.  All tests in the ER were good, and the EKG and ECO came back normal as well.  Since then I've had a few more panic attacks, but the anxiety has gotten better with time.  What hasn't gotten better is my health.  I've gotten a few colds, I had strep throat, an infection in my nose where the polyp removed was, pain in my stomach, and the chest pain is still there and has spread to my right chest area as well.  It's around the sternum, and the lower and upper rib area mostly.  I had another ECO done as well as an ultrasound of my liver, spleen, gallbladder, and aorta, and everything is normal.  I had a stool test for bacteria and it was normal.  Blood work, normal.  II even saw a chiropractor cause he said it's probably back related, and after 10 visits, nothing.  The pain comes and goes, but its still there.  I don't know what other tests to do.  Im supposed to have an endoscopy done soon, and I take Omeprazole for acid reflux.  Ive also had pain in my lower stomach, have gone to the bathroom more than usual to urinate, stkill get the stomach pains, and have even developed a pain that also comes and goes in the area between my testicles, and rectum.  Could this really be all b/c of anxiety, or is something wrong that they still haven't discovered?  This is all frustrating b/c I've always been healthy, rarely get colds, and this came about one day out of the blue (the chest pain) after I took a Nitric Oxide supplement to work out.  Help me out here please.  Thank you for your time/

author: Med2009  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Jan 21, 2006 3:13 pm Location: Vancouver
title: Chest Pain/Tightness
content: Hello.  I am a 22 year old male.  I live an active life: 2 marathons in last two years (3:34 & 3:19) & gym 3-4 times/week.  My last marathon was in May 2005.  For the past few months, I have been battling severe heartburn and abdominal pain.  Barium swallow test showed "severe reflux with mild gastritis".  Had a gastroscopy that was normal.  I also have mild swallowing problems.  Currently taking Pariet 20mg once daily & sometimes Gaviscon on top to relieve heartburn.  I am a tense type of person with lots of stress and feel that my symptoms do get worse during stressful times.    Along with the GI related issues, I am also having chest pain/tightness & back pain.  The chest pain is almost always localized in the left side.  The pain radiates laterally to my rib cage and superiorly to my neck and shoulders.  I also sometimes feel that my left arm is a bit numb.  The chest/back problems are made much worse when I go running.  Also, I develop abdominal cramps and belch alot.  For these reasons,  I have not been able to run for the past couple of months.  However, other exercises such as EFX, stepmill, bike, and stepper do not cause chest pain/tightness despite the fact that I do these exercises at fairly high intensity.  My breathing has not been affected but I do feel a slight chest pain in my left side when I take a very deep breath.  I just had an ECG and am waiting for the results.  I have a family history of atherosclerosis on my grandmother's side (my dad's mom) but my parents are fine.  My cholestrol test from 2003 was normal.    I am beginning to think that it may be esophageal spasms but the chest pain/tightness is at times present 24 hours a day.  Any ideas?

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Chest pain/tightness
content: Dear Med2009,  To evaluate the probability that chest pain is related to coronary disease or not, two things are looked at. The first is risk factors for coronary disease that the patient has and the second is the characteristics of the chest pain.  From your history, other than being a male, you don't have any major risk factors for coronary disease (assuming you are a non-smoker because of your history of running marathons and other vigoirous exercise). The characteristics of your chest pain are atypical as compared to the pain of coronary disease. This means that it is highly unlikely that your chest pain is related to coronary disease.  This chest pain could be related to your severe reflux disease, pariet at the current dose and gaviscon every now and then might not be doing the job. You might need to increase the dose and the freqnecy of taking pariet or may be switch to a different medication of the same category.   Other causes of atypical chest pain include: - Mitral valve prolapse, a benign condition that only need to be watched.   - Neck spine problems specially that you are complaining of having problems with neck pain and numbness sometimes. - Esophageal spasms can certainly be the reason behind the chest pain. - Mild inflammation of the ribs and cartilages can be the reason as well. - This does not sound like an inflammation of the membrane surrounding the lung but can certainly be.  So, i recommend that you discuss this with your doctor and if thought to be indicated, to have an echocardiogram (an ultrasound of the heart to look for mitral valve prolapse) and an x-ray or a cat scan of your neck spine (to look for neck spine problems such as arthritis), and may be a chest x-ray to make sure that everything is ok.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Tue Feb 28, 2006 2:12 pm

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  You are unduely worried.  From your description the most likely cause of the flutter is called "myokimia". This is nothing but a fibrillating motion of muscle fibres of your chest muscles. This is benign and the best course is to neglect the same.   The sleeping of the left arm mostly could be due to a cervical spondylosis, which compresses the nerve bundle passing out to your arm. This can be confirmed by an x ray of the neck. However some shoulder exercises and hot fomentation over the neck area will help.  Dr. A. Madia

title: Near-syncope
content: I am a 36-yr old female. My only surgeries have been for strabismus and the removal of my gall bladder, all over 5 yrs ago. I have had one child, 2.5 yrs old, no complications with pregnancy or delivery. I currently take Ambien CR occasionally for sleep problems (only a few times a month) and lorazepam for anxiety. The anxiety causes a very strong and rapid heartbeat in response to mild stress. I take the drug as infrequently as possible becasue of its addictiveness. I am also on the Nuva Ring for birth control.  For many years, I have had a rapid reasting heartbeat (90-100 bpm) I recently took my pulse after merely walking across a room and it was 120. Short walks or efforts seem to get me out of breath. In the last 3 or 4 months I have had three episodes of feeling like my heart "skipped a beat" accompanied by a feeling of almost passing out. This only lasts a few seconds. At the time that each of these episodes happened, I had not recently taken any meds and was not doing anything strenuous or under any kind of emotional stress. The first time I was lying on the sofa reading a good book!   I am scheduled for an echocardiogram today. All my EKGs have been normal. What can the echo show and what should happen next if it, too, is normal?
posted_time: Post  by dsmithd1 » Tue Feb 21, 2006 9:47 am

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  The most common result that your Echocardiogram might show in  this instance  is a Mitral Prolapse. This is a condition where the valve leaflets are long and redundant and they slip or "skid" over each other when they close with a force during the systole.  This can cause occurence of "missed" beats, palpitation, fast pulse and even a syncope.  This is a totally benign condition, and more of a nuisance value. You may need to take Inderal 40 mg twice a day which will contol the pulse, the missed beats and even the anxiety part too.   Dr. A. Madia

author: MRROBP  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Mon Sep 20, 2004 2:12 pm Location: MI
title: [no title]
content: This is in response to lilnell's post: -First off, I am not a doctor, med student, etc. I do however, possess a large amount of knowledge related to exercise. With that said:  -If your doctors have checked your heart several times, then what you're experiencing during exercise likely isn't due to your heart. Yet at the same time, it is related to it. Since you have been (self-admittedly) inactive for several years, if you just suddenly start exercising your body will simply not be used to the exertion. An obvious response is increased heart-rate, along with side pains and breathlessness.   Due to the fact that exercise is something your body is not used to, and it sounds like you're 'out of shape,' you need to start off any exercise program extremely slow. If you try to do too much, you're running the risk of severe injury or worse. I'd recommend you speak to your doctor about what is and isn't appropriate for you to do, exercise-wise. He or she should review your medical history, your current phyiscal condition, and overall general health, and basically tell you what you can safely do to start off with. While it might not seem like much, any exercise is better than none. If you can only safely walk on a treadmill at 1.0mph, with no incline, so be it. You're exercising, and that's what counts.  Again, I am not a doctor or in any medical profession. The above is purely my input on your situation lilnell.

author: RonInNJ  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Jan 27, 2006 10:12 am Location: NJ
title: Chest pain after cardiac episode
content: Hi.  I am a 53yo male who had a "cardiac episode" 4 yrs ago.  I had what seemed to be gall bladder type pain for about 2 hours at a time over 3 days. When finally visiting a doctor who did some testing there were anomalies in my ECG (in the recovery portion of my heart beat).   After extensive testing including a thallium stress test it was decided to do an angiogram.  (The scan showed some area of damage.)  The doctors, expecting to see some major blockages, reported no blockages at all, and my heart was free of any deposits.  The blockage that caused the problem was probably a clot that cleared on its own.  I was pronounced free of disease and go live my life.  Since that time I have had on and off chest pain and palpitations.  Sometimes it's a sharp pain, other times a squeezing pain that slowly realeases, usually preceeded by several days of palpitations.   Since the event 4 yrs ago (diagnosed as a "cardiac anomolie") I have had 4 stress tests with thalium scans.  Each test shows a well functioning heart with no limitations.  Any signs of damage and ECG problems had quickly disappeared after the original event .  The ECG returned to normal within 3 weeks. The doctors are getting tired of my complaints, often diagnosed as costochondritis (to keep me happy!) and no one seems to be listening to my pain complaints which have been with me from the time of the original event.   I exercise regularly and I am about to train for a climb of Mt. Rainier this summer (the toughest endurance climb in the continental US).   I have been given a clean bill of health, but with this pain I have a nagging feeling one day I'll just keel over....not the worst way to go!  Frequent treadmill work and bicycling present no agina like pain, can exercise with intensity for some time.  Most of the pains I have are while sitting or being inactive. Any advice? I have seen my own doctor as well as a cardiologist over the last 4 yrs. Ron

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi Sweety,  Causes of left arm pain are many.  Right from a cardiac anginal pain it could be a pain from cervical spondylosis, frozen shoulder, fibromyalgia, etc.  From the description of your symptoms it looks more like a spondylosis. I would advise you to get an X ray of Cervical Spine Lateral view and if spondylosis is threre you will need to take Physiotherapy, Short Wave diathermy and Traction to relieve the pain. after a 2 week course of the same you may continue physiotherapy exercises at home.  Cardiac pain at your age { in a woman of menstruating age } is quite uncommon although not unknown. If tou have predisposing factors like a family history, High Blood pressure, Diabetes mellitus, or High lipid levels, you may require and Echo and a stress ECG.  Get back to me with the result of the Cervical X ray and also with more details if required.  Dr A. Madia,

author: tkchicago  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Feb 01, 2006 9:45 pm
title: feelings of weakness centered on chest
content: I am a 26-year old male, 5'9", about 20 to 30 pounds overweight. Don't smoke, drink in moderation. No current medications. No past diagnoses of medical conditions, no surgeries. Both parents alive, in mid-50s, father is obese with high cholesterol and hypertension, no heart attacks in either case, but mother has a congenital heart murmur. About three years ago, I started intermittently (a few times per month) experiencing a feeling of weakness centered in my chest, as though my heart skipped a beat, although I don't really know what happened. It lasted about 1 second or less and it felt like I lost all my strength for an instant. It usually occurred while sitting down, but sometimes seemed to be triggered by standing up. It was usually in connection with a brief period of excitement. But it never occurred in connection with exertion due to exercise (I did a cardio workout, 45-min with a 150 heartrate average almost every day for six months). About 6 weeks ago, the symptoms got worse: feelings of weakness several times per day (occurred sometimes while completely calm and relaxed), which was a lot more frequent, plus a chronic feeling of tension and pain in the chest. There was occasionally a burning sensation in the chest. I ate a lot of unhealthy, processed foods, and I thought for some reason it might have something to do with sodium. I cut my intake to about 500 mg a day. The symptoms went away completely after 3 or 4 days. This was about 3 weeks ago. I started doing cardio exercises again, with no ill effects. Earlier tonight, I was sitting on the couch and felt two instances of weakness within 30 seconds. They were both accompanied by stabbing pains in the middle of the chest. Neither lasted more than 2 seconds. I never felt this sharp pain before. Today I wasn't so careful and probably ate about 2000 mg of sodium over the course of the day before this happened. I was worried mostly by the stabbing pain, which never happened before.   My question is, would these symptoms normally be associated with salt intake? What are the conditions that might explain this? Do you think the situation might be urgent? At this point I don't have insurance. I just got a new job and my insurance coverage starts in about 2 months, and I would like to see a cardiologist then. I did see two different GPs about it a while back, before the period of increased symptoms, they took my blood pressure (don't know what it was), listened to my chest, said it was probably stress. I didn't press the matter, unfortunately.  Thank you for your time and for any input.
posted_time: Post  by tkchicago » Wed Feb 01, 2006 10:36 pm

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  You look like having venticular ectopics from your description. In common language it is known as 'missed beats'. They come and go any time and they are more prone to occur at the time of excitement. At your age the reason could simply be a Mitral Prolapse. This is an innocent condition and easily treatable.  The relation with sodium intake is a little tenuous. Sodium would increase the BP but this would not generally cause missed beats. It is likely that all foods containing high sodium would also be high in oils and spices. These would in turn lead to hyperacidity and reflux in to the esophagus and this CAN cause ectopics in some patients.  My advice is, take it easy, reduce your salt intake,and wait out for 2 months, it wont harm you. As soon as 2 months are over, consult a cardiologist, get ECG, Stress ECG and Echocardiogram done, and the diagnosis will be clear.   Dr. A. Madia

author: MedStudent  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Mon Jan 30, 2006 3:54 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello Sweetish,  Before anything, let me just preface this by stating that I am a student doctor.  As always, no internet medical professional can substitute for the knowledge and experience of your family doctor.    Before anything, it's important that you answer the following questions to gauge a better understanding of what's going on.  1. What is your past medical history? 2. Are you taking any medications?  3. Besides the gallbladder removal and c-sections, have you had any other hospitalizations/ surgeries? 4. What is your social history (i.e Diet, Alcohol, Smoking, Married, Kids)?  Otherwise, in regards to your complaint, it sounds a lot like anxiety.  With the amount of televised ads for heart attacks and depression, it's not uncommon for anxiety to kick into effect.   Coupling that along with your family history, it's not hard to understand that you would be apprehensive.    I would recommend that you and your doctor set a goal for your health.  If you are classified as being overweight, you should plan to eat healither and exercise.  Afterall, chances of experiencing heart disease significantly reduce with exercise, healthy diet, smoking cessation, and healthy social interactions!  I would urge you to relax and distract yourself when commercials about  heart attack and depression come on.    As far as more tests are concerned, it is a possiblity that you are experiencing some esophogeal related symptoms.

title: heart murmur/ heart problem or anxiety disorder? Advice?
content: Hi,  I'm 29 and female. I've experienced for the past months many symptoms that are getting hard to cope with, but I haven't told my Dr, in fear that it might be just an anxiety disorder. The Dr did tell me I have a heart murmur (she discovered it last week on a routinary examination) and asked me to have an echocardiogram done in a few months (When my insurance will cover the cost) As I didn't mention any symptoms or anything she said that we'll know in that test but that she thought it was a functional or innocent heart murmur, since I don't have any other symptoms. The cardiologist who did an electrocardiogram told me to have that test done as soon as my insurance covers it (3 months from now) Well, the symptoms I've been having for the past months (which could very well be part of an anxiety disorder) are: - I can't breathe, I find it really hard to breathe, even when I'm not nervous or anything, when I'm walking, or when I"m in bed, or wherever or even having a good time. I start to feel all out of breath. I get a sharp chest pain, as if my heart skipped a heartbeat, or couldn't beat well, it beats strongly and it hurts in my chest, and it makes me dizzy and has made me faint several times. I find it really hard to cope with the shortness of breath and the sharp pain in my chest, it makes me faint. I've often put a wet towel on my chest to relieve the pain but it feels so hard, as if someone were pressing really tight on my chest and not letting me breathe  or my heart beat. It is a sharp pain and lack of breath. What other symptoms should I look for?  Of course, those symptoms I've mentioned could be symptoms of anxiety/panic attacks, so I truly don't know if I should take them seriously or not.  Thanks in advance for any info you can give me.  I was embarrassed to mention these symptoms to my Dr when she mentioned the heart murmur, because I am afraid they might just be a sign of severe anxiety.   Please can you help?  Thanks Julie (29)

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  You seem to be having a condition called Mitral valve Prolpase. This is a condition in which one of the four heart valves, the mitral valve has longer leaflets that usual. So when the valve closes the leaflets either buckle up or "skid" just like a car tyre skidding on wet road. This is a benign condition and does nor produce any complications apart from anxiety on the patients part.  You should undergo an Echocardiogram to confirm this and also a stress test just to rule out any serious ischemic heart problem.  But just relax and enjoy life rather than worry about heart. If confirmed to be a mitral prolapse, two tabs of Inderal a fay will resolve the issue.   Dr. A Madia

content: Hi.  You have a strong family history of vascular disease. author: jinkus  Guest Posts: 15 Joined: Tue Mar 22, 2005 2:53 pm Location: Derby
title: Here We Go Again!
content: My story starts about 7 months ago, I was at work and suddenly started having a pain in my chest. I went to the ER to be checked out and everything was reported to be fine. The pains came and went in no particular pattern for the next week or so, I went to see my GP who arranged for some tests to try and fatham out what the cause of my problems were. This pain was getting worse and I was starting to have other symptoms such as shortness of breath, and pins and needles (Pins and needles probably caused by Hyperventilation). I was admitted to hospital for in depth tests and amonst other tests I had a CT Scan and an MRI scan, the report came back stating I had a 3mm "Nodule" on the Pituitry Gland at the base of my Brain, this came as a sevre shock to my system as I was taken into hospital with chest pains!. Now the Nodule was reported not to be cancerous and they were happy to let me go after 5 days in Hospital. Now my chest pains are still there, not as bad as before, but the main concern I have is I am often having what I can only describe as a Skipped Beat sensation, it comes out of the blue and makes me jump, its a strange sensation that moves up my body, this is very worring to me and I am truly petrified there is something wrong with my heart or something else major. To date I have had 2 Echocardiograms, numerous chest/back X-Rays, a CT Scan, an MRI Scan, a Barium Meal, 24 Heart Monitor test, and I have lost count on the amount of Blood tests I have gone through. I have had a slight Pericardial Effusion which was very very minimal and my 24 hour heart test reported 1 ectopic beat.   I am still getting these sensations, even as I write this, my doctors are baffled Im baffled and I feel I have no were to turn. Im scared to go to work in case something happens, im scared to drive to far away from home in case im on my own and something happens, its a joke. I feel depressed, I cant sleep at night as im frightened in case I never wake up. I cant go to my doctor as I get the impression he is fed up of seeing me, I cant go to Hospital as I need to be referred by my doctor, I cant go Private as I need to be referred by my doctor. So Im left asking myself what do i do, do I wait until whatever is causing this Kills me, or do I beat it to it. Before I had this problem I was a fun loving normal 22 year old guy who enjoed life, enjoyed his work, and was truly happy, now im so far away from that I could just sit down and cry, and for me to say that is a big thing.   If anyone can offer any advice, or any answers as to what it might be, or if anyone reads this and has experienced simalar problems then please please reply to this as I really am scared and I don't know what to do next.  Sean

content: If you don't feel comfortable going back to your present doctor I guess I would suggest finding another one. Nothing wrong with a second opinion. As far as you "beating the disease to it" as you said...if you're seriously thinking about hurting yourself then you should speak to someone about that also.
